   133.01  OFFICE OF CITY CLERK.
   The office of City Clerk is hereby established. The City Clerk shall perform
the following duties:
   (a)   Provide, as assigned, a centralized clerical and records retention
service for all City departments and agencies.
   (b)   Issue licenses and permits as assigned.
   (c)   Provide an information service at the City Hall.
   (d)   Perform such other duties as may be assigned by the City Manager.
      (Ord. 90-64. Passed 10-12-64; Ord. 69-71. Passed 11-8-71.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 135
Department of Law
 
135.01   Duties of Director.
135.02   Appointment of Prosecutor and Assistant Prosecutors.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Department creation - see CHTR.
 3.04; ADM.
131.04
      Statutory powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 733.51 et seq.
 
   135.01 DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Department of Law shall be under the direction of the Director of Law
who shall be accountable to the City Manager. He shall perform the following
duties:
   (a)   Attend all regular and special meetings of Council as requested, and
attend Council committee meetings and meetings of boards and commissions as
requested.
   (b)   Advise Council, the City Manager, boards, commissions and all officers
and departments of the City on all matters of law.
   (c)   Draft or cause to be drafted all ordinances, resolutions, agreements
and contracts to be made or entered into by the City and approve the form of
such instruments.
   (d)   Prosecute all violators of the City ordinances and represent the City
in all actions at law.
   (e)   Review and report to Council on the official bonds of all officers of
the City.
   (f)   Give his opinion upon any legal question affecting the City government
submitted to him by Council or any of its committees, or by any City official.
   (g)   Perform such other duties as may be required by the City Manager.
   (h)   Perform all legal services incident to public improvements and the
issuance of notes and bonds in payment thereof or make arrangements for the
hiring of special counsel.
 
   135.02  APPOINTMENT OF PROSECUTOR AND ASSISTANT PROSECUTORS.
   (a)   The Director of Law shall appoint the City Prosecutor. The Director of
Law, in consultation with the City Prosecutor, shall appoint Assistant City
Prosecutors.
   (b)   In addition to such other qualifications as the Director of Law may
reasonably require, the City Prosecutor and the Assistant City Prosecutors
shall, at a minimum, be and remain, during his or her term in office, an
attorney admitted to the Bar of Ohio and be and remain, during his or her term
of office, in good standing with the Supreme Court of Ohio.
   (c)   Both the City Prosecutor and the Assistant City Prosecutors may
represent the City in a prosecutorial capacity in criminal and traffic cases
pending, or in which the future might be pending, in the Franklin County
Municipal Court, both in the Criminal and Civil Divisions; and
   (d)   The Prosecutor and Assistant City Prosecutors shall have and exercise
the same powers as the Director of Law but only in connection with the
prosecution of criminal and traffic cases in the Mayor’s Court or the Franklin
County Municipal Court.
(Ord. 66-2004. Passed 1-3-05.)

 4.05 et seq.

111
 
   137.01  DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Department of Finance shall be under the direction of the Director of
Finance who shall be accountable to the City Manager. He shall perform the
following duties:
   (a)   Keep in proper books a full and accurate account of all the moneys
received and disbursed by him on behalf of the City as well as all outstanding
sums due the City and all orders and contracts upon which the City is
obligated.
   (b)   Receive and have custody of all moneys paid to the City and to
disburse City moneys in accordance with the City Charter and ordinances.
   (c)   Render regular reports to Council reflecting the financial condition
of the City.
   (d)   Certify that funds are available according to law to pay all
contracts, agreements or other obligations for the expenditure of public funds
entered into by any official of the City government, and no such contract,
agreement or other obligation shall be valid until so certified by him.
   (e)   Keep an accurate account of the bonded debt of the City and of the
payment of interest and principal thereon.
   (f)   Prepare the City payroll.
   (g)   Administer all employee benefit funds.
   (h)   Prepare and submit such reports as may be required by law.
   (i)   Assist the City Manager in preparing the preliminary drafts of the
annual budget.
   (j)   Compile bond transcripts and notes.
   (k)   Perform such other duties as may be required by the City Manager.
      (Ord. 90-64. Passed 10-12-64.)
   (l)   Serve as the Income Tax Administrator unless otherwise provided by
ordinance. (A.O.)
   (m)   Examine and account for the funds of those community organizations
receiving moneys directly from the General Fund on an annual basis not later
than the end of the fiscal year of each community organization.
      (Ord. 126-92. Passed 1-11-93.)
 
   137.02 DIRECTOR AS FISCAL OFFICER.
   The Director of Finance shall be the fiscal officer of the City, and fiscal
agent of the City in all transactions under the Uniform Bond Law.
 
   137.03 SIGNATURE OF NOTES AND BONDS.
   The President of Council and the Director of Finance are designated as
officials to sign all notes and/or bonds issued by the City, except those
authorized by Section
 4.13 of the City Charter.
 
   137.04 DIRECTOR'S DUTIES AS SUCCESSOR TO CLERK AND TREASURER.
   The Director of Finance shall perform all duties prescribed by ordinance or
required by the laws of the State of Ohio not inconsistent with the provisions
of the City Charter, which duties shall include those previously performed by
the Clerk and Treasurer of the City.
 
   137.05 ACCRUAL ACCOUNTS.
   The Director of Finance shall establish and maintain an accrual system of
accounting which shall reveal at all times not only the cash position of the
City by funds, but also the revenue and income anticipated and the obligations
outstanding and unpaid.
 
   137.06 CONTRACTS AND PURCHASE ORDERS.
   No City official or employee shall have authority to create an obligation
against the City by oral agreement. Purchases shall be made by written purchase
order signed by the Purchasing Agent, and agreements for construction work or
for personal services shall be by written contract or appointment signed by the
City Manager or an administrative officer of the City designated by him. No
purchase order or contract shall be valid as an obligation of the City unless
it bears a certificate signed by the Director of Finance that the estimated
amount thereof has been entered as an encumbrance in the City accounts against
an allotment based on a valid appropriation.
 
   137.07 PROCESSING PURCHASE ORDERS AND CONTRACTS; ENCUMBRANCE CERTIFICATION.
   Whenever a purchase order is prepared by the Director of Finance and any
contract is submitted for encumbrance and certification, the Director shall
examine the accounts to determine whether or not there is an unencumbered
balance remaining in the amount allotted for the purpose to the account against
which it is proposed that the purchase or contract be charged. If the
unencumbered balance of the allotment is adequate, he shall encumber such
balance by the amount of the purchase order or contract and enter upon the face
of such purchase order or contract the following certificate which he shall
sign:
"It is hereby certified that the amount ($ ) required to meet the contract,
agreement, obligation, payment or expenditure for the above has been lawfully
appropriated or authorized or directed for such purpose and is in the Treasury
or in process of collection to the credit of the                       Fund
free from any obligation or certification now outstanding."
Date                                                          
              Director of Finance
   He shall retain a copy for his files. (Reference Ohio R.C. 5705.41)
 
   137.08 SIGNATURE AND DELIVERY OF PURCHASE ORDERS AND CONTRACTS.
   Each purchase order certified as properly encumbered shall be sent to the
vendor as his authority for performance. Each contract when certified as
properly encumbered shall be delivered to the City Manager who shall sign the
same on behalf of the City and send a copy to the contractor as his authority
for performance. Any goods delivered or work performed prior to the date of
issue of the purchase order or contract, legally signed and delivered, shall be
entirely at the risk of the vendor or contractor.
 
   137.09 INVOICES; CERTIFICATION OF QUANTITY AND QUALITY.
   Vendors who supply goods or services in response to purchase orders shall
deliver such goods or services in compliance with the terms thereof. When they
have performed the obligations which rest upon them under such purchase orders,
they shall render invoices therefor, and on such invoices they shall enter the
number and date of the pertinent purchase order. Each invoice shall be
delivered first to the agency which received the goods or services, which shall
prepare and sign a certificate of the following tenor: "The goods and/or
services covered by this invoice have been received by this agency and were of
the quantity and quality specified in the purchase order and billed on this
invoice. Signed                         " The certificate shall also certify
that the computations on the invoice have been audited and found correct.
 
   137.10 PROCESSING INVOICES; CHECK ISSUANCE.
   All invoices shall be delivered promptly to the Department of Finance which
shall prepare a voucher and audit it to see that it is complete and correct and
that the order was legally made. The outstanding encumbrances shall be credited
and the cash balance debited in each case and a check written in payment. Any
adjustments due to shortages in deliveries, reductions in price or discounts
taken shall be made when the entries affecting encumbered balances are made.
Checks shall be signed by the Director of Finance and by the City Manager and
shall be delivered promptly to the claimants.
 
   137.11  PAYROLL APPROVAL AND PAYMENT.
   The payrolls prepared by the Director of Finance shall be examined by the
Personnel Director, who shall approve those on which the employees named
thereon have been legally appointed and are shown thereon by proper class
titles and approved rates of pay. The payroll shall then be finally approved by
the City Manager, and the Director of Finance shall prepare, sign and deliver
checks for the amounts shown to the employees named. It shall not be necessary
to encumber payrolls before payment or to certify to the availability of funds
appropriated for personal services, except those obtained on a contractual
basis.
 
   137.12 PAYMENTS ON CONTRACTS.
   Payments on signed contracts shall be made in strict accordance with the
terms of such contracts when the conditions laid down in such contracts have
been faithfully complied with by the contractor. Invoices for partial payments
on construction contracts shall bear the certificate of the City Engineer as to
the percentage of completion of the contract at the date of the invoice and no
payment shall be made of a greater proportion of the contract price than has
been completed. Invoices against contracts shall be credited against
outstanding encumbrances and charged against cash expenditures before they are
paid. Checks for payment of invoices against contracts shall be prepared by the
Director of Finance, and signed by him and the City Manager. Such checks shall
be delivered promptly to the contractors.
 
   137.13 ACCRUAL OF REVENUES.
   The Director of Finance shall open an account for each source of City
revenue, debiting the estimated revenue, as used in the City budget, and
crediting collections as received. The balance at any time represents the
accrual of revenues still to be collected if the budget is to be covered.
 
   137.14  FINANCIAL REPORT TO COUNCIL AND CITY MANAGER.
   The Director of Finance shall report at least quarterly to the City Manager
and to Council on the status of all funds, all appropriations, all revenue
estimates and collections, all allotments and all expenditures, as well as bond
redemption and interest payments made and due to be made during the fiscal
year.
 
   137.15 BOND FOR DIRECTOR.
   The Director of Finance shall furnish to the Clerk a corporate surety bond
issued by a company authorized to do business in Ohio, to protect the City
against loss due to his acts. The amount of such bond shall be one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000), and the premium on such bond shall be paid by the
City.
(Ord. 109-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
 
   137.16 CORPORATE SURETY BOND FOR ACCOUNT CLERK.
   The Account Clerk shall furnish to the Clerk a corporate surety bond issued
by a company authorized to do business in Ohio, to protect the City against
loss due to his acts. The amount of such bond shall be one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000), and the premium on such bond shall be paid by the City.
(Ord. 109-81. Passed 12-28-81.)

   EDITOR'S NOTE: Council by resolution has enacted classification and

   139.01  DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Department of Personnel shall be under the direction of the Director of
Personnel who shall be accountable to the City Manager and shall perform the
duties prescribed by City Charter Section
11.03.
 
   139.02  PERSONNEL POLICY.
   The basic personnel policy of the City shall be that:
   (a)   Employment in the City government shall be based on merit and fitness,
free from personal, racial, religious and political considerations.
   (b)   Recruitment shall be conducted on a broad basis in order to assure an
adequate field of selection.
   (c)   Just and equitable incentives and conditions of employment shall be
established and maintained in order to promote efficiency and economy in the
operation of the City government.
   (d)   Positions having similar duties and responsibilities shall be
classified and compensated on a uniform basis.
   (e)   Appointments, promotions and other personnel actions shall be based on
systematic tests and evaluations.
   (f)   Tenure of employees shall be subject to good behavior, the
satisfactory performance of work, necessity for the performance of work and the
availability of funds.
 
   139.03  PERMANENT STATUS.
   All persons holding positions not included among those exempted by Charter
Section
11.02 shall have a permanent status if:
   (a)   They were employed in such positions on November 18, 1957, the date on
which the City Charter became effective;
   (b)   They had served satisfactorily in the positions they now hold for a
period of six months before the effective date of this section (Ordinance 48-
59, passed May 4, 1959); or
   (c)   They shall serve a probationary period of six months or such longer
period as may be prescribed under the provisions of this chapter.
 
   139.04 CLASSIFICATION PLAN.
   The nonexempt positions in the service of the City shall be called the
classified service. The Personnel Director shall make an analysis of the duties
and responsibilities of all positions in the classified service and recommend
to Council, through the City Manager, a position classification plan. Each
position in the classified service shall be classified on the basis of the kind
and level of its duties and responsibilities. A class may include one position
or more than one position, and each class shall have a descriptive title which
shall be used for all personnel purposes including budget and payrolls. After
approval by Council of the initial classification plan by resolution, the
Personnel Director shall allocate each existing position to its appropriate
class. The class to which each position is initially allocated shall be the
class in which the employee shall have status under the provisions of Section
139.03.
 
   139.05  COMPENSATION PLAN.
   The Personnel Director, under the direction of the City Manager and in
consultation with the Director of Finance, shall prepare a compensation plan
which shall include all classes of positions covered by the classification
plan. The rate or range for each class shall be such as to reflect fairly the
difference in duties and responsibilities and shall be related to compensation
for comparable positions in other places of public and private employment. The
plan shall be presented to Council through the City Manager and, when approved
by Council by resolution, shall be applied to all positions and classes of
positions then in existence, in the manner provided in such resolution.
 
   139.06 AMENDMENT OF CLASSIFICATION AND COMPENSATION PLANS.
   The initial classification plan shall be kept up to date by the addition of
new classes or the abolition, consolidation, division or amendment of existing
classes by recommendation of the Personnel Director and City Manager, and
approval by resolution of Council. The compensation plan may be similarly
amended either through adjustment of rates or by reassignment of classes of
positions to different pay ranges, on recommendation by the Personnel Director
and City Manager, and approval by resolution of Council.
 
   139.07 RECRUITMENT AND SELECTION.
   Original appointments to vacancies occurring shall be based on merit as
determined by competitive examinations. Requirements as to applicant
qualifications shall be provided by rule established by the Personnel Director.
The Personnel Director shall determine the time and place of examinations and
shall post an advertisement for applications on the City's website and in such
other media as the Director shall determine expedient. The Director shall
prescribe the form of the application and shall conduct such investigation as
the Director deems necessary as to the truth of the statements made therein and
as to the qualifications of the applicant. The Director shall have authority to
exclude from the examination any applicant whose application discloses that he
or she does not possess the minimum qualifications established in the
classification plan for the position sought. The Director may also require all
applicants to be fingerprinted. Examinations shall be in such form as will
fairly test the abilities and aptitudes of the candidates to perform the duties
of the position sought. The Director shall determine the nature of the
examination and the weight to be attributed to each part and shall grade or
shall cause the examinations to be graded.
(Ord. 01-2017. Passed 1-17-17.)
 
   139.08  VETERANS PREFERENCE.
   Preference in entrance examinations, but not in promotion, shall be granted
to qualified persons who have been members of the armed forces of the United
States in time of war or national emergency and who seek to enter the service
of the City within five years immediately following their honorable discharge
from military service. Such preference shall be in the form of points added to
the final grades of such person, provided that they first attain a passing
grade of seventy percent (70%). The preference shall be five points for a
nondisabled veteran and ten points for a veteran currently receiving
compensation from the United States Veterans' Administration for war service
incurred disabilities of more than ten percent (10%). Eligibility for a veteran
preference credit shall be established by presentation of original discharge
papers or a photostat copy thereof.
 
   139.09 ELIGIBLE LISTS.
   Candidates who qualify for employment shall be placed upon an original
appointment eligible list for the appropriate class of position, in the rank
order of the grades they obtain on the examinations. The rank order of
candidates who are allowed veterans' preference shall be based on their
augmented ratings. Permanent employees laid off for lack of funds or work shall
be placed upon a re-employment eligible list. A probationary employee who is
laid off while the original appointment eligible list from which he was
appointed is still effective shall be restored to his original place on that
list. Eligible lists shall be effective for one year and may be extended for
one additional year in the discretion of the Personnel Director.
 
   139.10  PROMOTIONS.
   Vacancies in positions above the entrance level shall be filled by promotion
whenever in the judgment of the City Manager and Personnel Director it is in
the best interests of the City to do so. Promotions shall be on a competitive
basis except where the Personnel Director finds that the number of persons
qualified for promotion is insufficient to justify competition. Promotional
examinations shall give appropriate consideration to the applicant's
qualifications, record of performance and seniority. Those found eligible for
promotion shall be placed upon a promotional eligible list for the class of
positions for which the examination was given, in the rank order of the
composite score attained.
 
   139.11  CERTIFICATION AND APPOINTMENT.
   Whenever a vacancy exists for an original appointment, the appointing
authority shall ask the Personnel Director to certify the name or names of
persons eligible for appointment. If there is any name on an appropriate re-
employment eligible list, it shall be certified and the person so certified
shall be appointed. If there is more than one name, appointment shall be made
first of the person whose name has been longest on the list. If there are no
names on an appropriate re- employment eligible list, certification shall be
made of the names of the six persons standing highest on the appropriate
original appointment eligible list. The appointing authority shall appoint one
of these, notifying the Personnel Director, so that the person appointed may be
placed upon the payroll and the persons not appointed may be restored to the
eligible list. When the vacancy is in a position above the entry level, and a
promotional eligible list exists, the Personnel Director shall certify the
three names standing highest on this list from which the appointing authority
shall appoint one, notifying the Personnel Director of his action. The
Personnel Director shall furnish one additional name for each person who
indicates in writing to the appointing officer his unwillingness to accept
appointment.
(Ord. 40-96. Passed 5-13-96.)
 
   139.12 TEMPORARY APPOINTMENTS.
   Whenever an emergency exists which requires that a vacancy be filled at once
in order to maintain public services, the appointing authority may appoint any
qualified person temporarily to perform the duties of the position. However, no
such appointment shall be for a period longer than ninety days in any calendar
year.
(Ord. 42-99. Passed 7-26-99.)
 
   139.13  PROVISIONAL APPOINTMENTS.
   Whenever there is no eligible list from which a certification can be made,
the Personnel Director shall so inform the appointing authority and if in the
judgment of such appointing authority it is not expedient to await the
establishment of such a list, he shall submit the application of any person or
persons deemed by him to be suitable for noncompetitive examination. If on
review of the application and check of the references, the applicant is found
to possess the minimum qualifications established in the classification plan
for the position to be filled, the Personnel Director may authorize his
appointment as a provisional employee. A provisional appointment shall not be
for longer than three months during which an examination shall be given and an
eligible list established. The provisional appointee shall not be eligible for
regular appointment unless he has taken the examination and stands high enough
on the list to be reached for certification.
 
   139.14 PROBATION.
   Employees appointed from original appointment eligible lists and from
promotional eligible lists shall be subject to a period of probation. The
regular period of probation shall be six months, provided that the personnel
rules may specify a longer or shorter period of probation for certain
designated classes of positions, or for extension of the probation period in
individual cases. However, probation may not extend beyond twelve months. The
work and conduct of probationary employees shall be subject to close scrutiny
and evaluation and if found to be below standards satisfactory to the
appointing authority, the appointing authority may remove or demote the
probationer at any time during the probationary period. Such removals or
demotion shall not be subject to review or appeal. An employee shall be
retained beyond the end of the probationary period and granted permanent status
only if the appointing authority notifies the Personnel Director in writing
that his work has been found satisfactory and that he recommends that he be
given permanent status.
 
   139.15 RULES FOR WORK HOURS, ABSENCES, VACATIONS AND LEAVES.
   Rules shall be adopted prescribing hours of work, and the conditions and
length of time for which leaves of absence with pay and leaves of absence
without pay may be granted. These shall cover, among other matters: vacations,
sick leaves, and leaves for military service.
 
   139.16 DISCIPLINE.
   The primary responsibility for the administration of discipline shall rest
upon the immediate supervisor of the employee to be disciplined, although if he
fails to take action, which in the opinion of his superior is justified, such
superior may himself impose the discipline. Disciplinary action taken against
an employee, which is other than in the nature of a minor first offense warning
shall be in writing and made a part of such employee's permanent personnel
file. The employee shall be given notice of any disciplinary action taken
against him together with the reasons therefor not later than the effective
date of such action. The notice shall inform the employee of his rights to have
his case reviewed in accordance with the provisions of Section
139.17, supra.
(Ord. 53-70. Passed 6-22-70.)
 
   139.17 GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE.
   Whenever an officer or permanent employee of the City feels aggrieved by the
action of his supervisor in the administration of discipline, he may present a
written statement of his grievance to the immediate supervisor of the
supervisor who administered the discipline within five working days of the
effective date of the disciplinary action taken against him, asking for a
review and reversal or modification of the disciplinary action. If such
grievance is not resolved to the satisfaction of the aggrieved employee by the
superior so addressed within a period of five working days, he may request in
writing, a review of his grievance by his department head, and if still
unresolved within five working days, he may request a review by the Personnel
Director. If the grievance is not resolved to the satisfaction of the aggrieved
employee by the Personnel Director within a period of ten working days, he may
request in writing a review of his case by the City Manager, provided the City
Manager has not already ruled on such case as a supervisor or the immediate
superior of the supervisor who administered the discipline.
   In all cases, the written ruling of the City Manager shall be final and
binding unless the disciplinary action taken against the employee and approved
by the City Manager involves suspension from duty without pay or demotion or
discharge, in which case the employee affected shall have the right to request
a hearing before the Personnel Appeals Board for purposes of reviewing the
final decision of the City Manager. Any such request for a hearing before the
Personnel Appeals Board must be submitted to the City Manager in writing within
five working days of the date of the City Manager's final decision and shall
specify in detail the reasons why the City Manager's decision is in error.
(Ord. 6-77. Passed 2-14-77.)
 
   139.18 PERSONNEL APPEALS BOARD.
   The City Manager shall report to Council each proper request for a hearing
before the Personnel Appeals Board filed under the provisions of Section
139.17. The Board shall have final authority to take action thereon. The City
Manager shall carry out the decision of the Board.
(Ord. 43-82. Passed 5-24-82.)
 
   139.19 RULES TO IMPLEMENT PERSONNEL MATTERS.
   The Personnel Director shall prepare, in consultation with the City Manager,
such rules as may be deemed desirable to carry out the provisions of the
Charter and of this chapter relative to personnel matters. Such rules shall be
reported to Council and unless amended or disapproved by resolution of Council
within thirty days after such report, shall become effective. Amendments and
supplements to the rules shall be made in the same manner.
 
   139.20 TRAINING.
   The Personnel Director shall encourage the improvement of service by
providing employees with opportunities for training not only for their present
position, but also for advancement and for general improvement and education.
 
   139.21 SEPARATION; REINSTATEMENT AFTER DISMISSAL.
   The tenure of every employee is conditioned upon good behavior and the
satisfactory performance of duties. Any employee may be permanently separated
by resignation or dismissal. The resignation of any employee other than the
City Manager shall become effective on acceptance by the City Manager, or if an
effective date is stated in the resignation, then on such date. Dismissals
shall become effective on the date specified in the order of removal. If an
employee is reinstated after dismissal, hearing by a Personnel Board of
Appeals, and approval of the report of the Board by Council, he shall be paid
his regular compensation for the period following his removal until his
restoration to duty.
 
   139.22 LAYOFFS.
   Whenever there is lack of work or lack of funds requiring a reduction in the
number of employees of the City, the required reduction shall be made in such
position classes as the appointing authority shall designate. Employees shall
be laid off in the inverse order of their relative length and quality of
service. Within each affected class, all temporary employees shall be laid off
before provisional employees, all provisional employees before probationary
employees, and all probationary employees before permanent employees.
 
   139.23 REINSTATEMENT AFTER VOLUNTARY RESIGNATION.
   An employee who resigns voluntarily may be reinstated to any position in the
same class and salary or in a class with equal or lesser salary requiring the
same or lesser skills, abilities and qualifications in the same department or
division if there is a need for the individual’s services within two years
after the date of resignation.
(Ord. 41-98. Passed 9-28-98.)
 
   139.24 RECORDS.
   The Personnel Director shall maintain adequate records of his own official
acts, the actions of all Personnel Appeals Boards, the examination record of
every candidate and the employment record of every employee.
 
   139.25  CLASS TITLE OF POSITION.
   The class title under which each position in the regular classified service
is known shall be used to designate such position in all budget estimates,
payrolls and other official records, documents, vouchers and communications,
and in all personnel processes.
 
   139.26 INITIAL RATES OF PAY.
   All appointments to positions in the classified service of the City shall
normally be made at the salary fixed in the lowest step of the appropriate
range. The City Manager may, however, authorize an appointment at a higher step
whenever the Personnel Director certifies to him that the City is unable to
recruit satisfactory employees at the lowest step, or when, on certification,
the Personnel Director recommends a higher step due to the training and
experience of the eligible candidate, provided funds are lawfully available.
 
   139.27  ADVANCEMENT.
   All increases in salary for persons in the classified service of the City
shall be made only upon recommendation of the division or department head to
the City Manager and then only if funds are lawfully available. Merit shall be
the primary basis for advancement in salary although seniority shall also be
considered. Such advancement shall normally be for only one step in the same
range.
 
   139.28 SALARY ON PROMOTION.
   Whenever a classified employee is promoted from a position in one class to a
position in a higher class, his new salary shall be fixed by the City Manager,
within available appropriations but shall not be less than the salary he
received before promotion.
 
   139.29 SALARY ON DEMOTION.
   Whenever a classified employee is demoted from a position in one class to a
position in a lower class, his new salary shall be fixed by the City Manager
within available appropriations at one of the step rates within the pay range
applicable to the position to which he has been demoted and in every case it
shall be less than the salary he received before demotion.
 
   139.30  SALARY ON REINSTATEMENT.
   Whenever a person is reinstated under the provisions of the personnel
ordinance, his salary shall be fixed by the City Manager within available
appropriations, at a step rate in the pay range applicable to the position to
which he has been reinstated, but in no case shall his salary immediately after
reinstatement be less than that received by him before he was granted leave,
laid off or otherwise separated from the service.
 
   139.31  SALARY FOR EXEMPT POSITIONS.
   Salaries for exempt positions other than for members of Council and the
Mayor shall be set by separate ordinance and shall be reviewed at least
annually.
 
   139.32 CORPORATE SURETY BOND FOR EMPLOYEES.
   All employees of the Municipality whose duties require them to handle or be
concerned with the management of its money or other property shall furnish to
the Clerk a corporate surety bond issued by a company authorized to do business
in Ohio, to protect the City against loss due to their acts. The amount of such
bond shall be fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) and the premium on such bond
shall be paid by the City.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 141
Department of Safety
 
141.01   Divisions and functions.
141.02   Division of Police.
141.03   Reserve Police Force.

 3.04; ADM.

   141.01  DIVISIONS AND FUNCTIONS.
   The Department of Safety shall be under the direction of the Director of
Safety. It shall be composed of the following divisions, which shall have the
functions hereinafter set forth and such others as may be delegated to it by
the City Manager:
   (a)   Police
   (b)   Fire
 
   141.02 DIVISION OF POLICE.
   The Division of Police shall be under the direction of a Chief of Police who
shall be accountable to the Director of Safety. He shall perform the following
duties:
   (a)   Formulate and administer procedures pertaining to the enforcement of
rules and regulations for the government and operation of the Police Division
including the reserve and auxiliary police forces.
   (b)   Be responsible for the preservation of the public peace and order, the
prevention and detection of crime, the apprehension of offenders, the
protection of persons and property, and the enforcement of law.
   (c)   Have control of the assignment of all police officers.
   (d)   Provide for the training and instruction of the officers and employees
of the Police Division.
   (e)   Act as a liaison officer with other law enforcement agencies.
   (f)   Perform such other duties as the Director of Safety may require.
   (g)   Serve as commanding officer of the reserve and auxiliary police
forces.
 
   141.03 RESERVE POLICE FORCE.
   (a)   Creation and Appointment. There is hereby created a reserve police
force, the members of which shall be appointed by the Director of Safety upon
the recommendation of the Chief of Police.
 
   (b)   Term. Reserve policemen shall serve at the pleasure of the Director of
Safety, or until a submitted resignation shall be accepted by the Director.
 
   (c)   Minimum Age. The members of the reserve police force may not be under
the age of twenty-one years at the time of their employment.
(Ord. 29-78. Passed 4-10-78.)
 
   (d)   Duties. The reserve police force will have all police powers, but
shall perform only such police duties as assigned by the Chief of Police, and
shall act only when in uniform as prescribed by the Director of Safety.
 
   (e)   Compensation. All services performed by reserve officers shall be on a
voluntary basis except that such officers shall receive one dollar ($1.00) per
year. All services performed shall be only when the reserve officer is on duty
and then only within the corporate limits of the City except when accompanying
a regular police officer outside the corporate limits of the City. Reserve
police officers shall serve without pay, except when the provisions of Chapter
507  of the General Offenses Code have been invoked and such reserve police
officers are requested to report to duty by the City Manager, Police Chief or
other official in charge, and do in fact report to duty and except when the
temporary absence of regular police officers requires that the City Manager or
the Police Chief request reserve police officers to assume temporarily the
duties of the regular police officers. In such cases, the reserve police
officers shall be compensated at a rate equal to the hourly rate less benefits
of a beginning level police officer for all hours for which they are on duty.
(Ord. 41-82. Passed 5-10-82.)
 
   (f)   Nonclassified Service; Workers' Compensation. Reserve police officers
shall be deemed to be not within the classified service of the City but shall,
nonetheless, be considered employees of the City when in performance of duties
pursuant to the laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of the City pertaining
to reserve police officers. Such reserve police officers shall be covered by
workers' compensation in accordance with Industrial Commission rules and
regulations pertaining to volunteer police officers and fire officers of public
employees.
(Ord. 29-78. Passed 4-10-78.)
 
   (g)   Bond and Uniform. Each member of the reserve police force, as a
condition precedent to serving thereon, shall furnish at City expense a bond in
the amount and upon the same terms and conditions as is required of a regular
appointed policeman. Each member of the reserve police force shall provide
himself with the prescribed uniform at his own expense.
 
   (h)   Liability Insurance. The City shall furnish and pay for the liability
insurance coverage for all active reserve police officers while performing
duties under this section.
(Ord. 29-78. Passed 4-10-78.)
 
   141.04  AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE.
   The Director of Safety may appoint, on recommendation of the Chief of
Police, such auxiliary police officers as he may deem necessary and as
appropriations may permit. Such auxiliary police officers shall not be less
than eighteen years of age, and in good physical condition. Auxiliary police
officers shall have the same authority as reserve police officers except that
they shall not be used on patrol duty and shall not be required to be in
uniform or to furnish bond. When used to supplement the police force, they
shall be paid such compensation as the Director of Safety may approve, within
existing appropriations. Each member of the auxiliary police shall be
considered to be an employee of the City and shall be paid compensation of one
dollar ($1.00) per year.
 
   141.05 DIVISION OF FIRE AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES.
   The Division of Fire and Emergency Medical Services shall be under the
direction of a Fire Chief who shall be accountable to the Director of Safety.
He/She shall perform the following duties:
   (a)   Formulate and administer procedures pertaining to the enforcement of
rules and regulations for the government and operation of the Division of Fire
and Emergency Medical Services.
   (b)   Be responsible for fire suppression, emergency medical services,
emergency environmental control, rescue services, fire and safety education,
fire prevention and inspection.
   (c)   Have control of the assignment and scheduling of all employees of the
Division.
   (d)   Provide for the training and instruction of the officers and employees
of the Division.
   (e)   Act as a liaison with governmental and private agencies and
institutions associated with the provision of fire and emergency services.
   (f)   Meet on a regular basis with the Medical Director of the Division to
ensure proper licensing and certifications required by the State for the
provision of emergency medical service.
   (g)   Perform such other duties as the Director of Safety may require.
(Ord. 86-93. Passed 10-12-93.)
 
   141.06 MEDICAL DIRECTOR OF THE DIVISION OF FIRE AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL
SERVICES.
   The Director of Safety shall appoint a Medical Director for the Division of
Fire and Emergency Medical Services to advise the Division on matters
pertaining to the provision of emergency medical services and certify
qualifications and licensure requirements as required by the State. The Medical
Director shall be a licensed physician in the State.
(Ord. 03-2003. Passed 1-21-03.)

   143.03 DIVISION OF ENGINEERING.

   (b)   Conduct engineering investigations of relevant City issues,

specifications and maps.

   151.02  RECORDS COMMISSION.
   (a)   There is hereby created a City Records Commission composed of the
Chief Executive, or the Chief Executive's appointed representative, as
Chairperson, and the Chief Fiscal Officer, the Chief Legal Officer, and a
Citizen appointed by the Chief Executive. The commission shall also appoint a
Secretary, who may or may not be a member of the commission, and who shall
serve at the pleasure of the commission.
   (b)   The functions of the commission shall be to provide rules for
retention and disposal of records of the municipal corporation and to review
applications for one-time disposal of obsolete records and schedules of record
retention and disposition submitted by municipal offices. The commission may
dispose of records pursuant to the procedure outlined in this section. The
commission at any time may review any schedule it has previously approved and
for good cause shown may revise that schedule.
   (c)   When the City Records Commission has approved any application for one-
time disposal of obsolete records or any schedule of records and disposition,
the commission shall send that application or schedule to the Ohio History
Connection for its review. The Ohio History Connection shall review the
application or schedule within a period of not more than sixty days after its
receipt of it. Upon completion of its review, the Ohio History Connection shall
forward the application for one-time disposal of obsolete records or the
schedule of records retention and disposition to the auditor of the state for
the auditor's approval or disapproval. The auditor shall approve or disapprove
the application or schedule within a period of not more than sixty days after
receipt of it.
   (d)   Before public records are to be disposed of pursuant to an approved
schedule of records retention and disposition, the records commission shall
inform the Ohio History Connection of the disposal through the submission of a
certificate of records disposal for only the records required by the schedule
to be disposed of, and shall give the Ohio History Connection the opportunity
for a period of fifteen business days to select for its custody those public
records, from the certificate submitted, that it considers to be of continuing
historical value.
(Ord. 50-2018. Passed 11-19-18.)
 
   151.03 PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION.
   (a)   Members; Term. There is hereby established a Parks & Recreation
Commission to be composed of nine voting members including two students who are
residents of the City of Worthington and are enrolled in high school at the
time of their appointment or who are in an equivalent grade in a district-
approved home school program. All members of the Parks and Recreation
Commission shall be appointed by Worthington City Council for terms of one to
two years as Council shall determine and specify at the time of making such
appointment, each term commencing on January 1.
(Ord. 37-2023. Passed 12-4-23.)
 
 
   (b)   Organization. The Parks and Recreation Commission shall organize
annually in January and elect a chairman, vice chairman and secretary.
 
   (c)   Advisory Capacity Only. The Parks and Recreation Commission shall act
solely in an advisory capacity to Council and all reports and proposals shall
be made to Council.
 
   (d)   Departmental Assistance. The Parks and Recreation Commission may call
upon the City Manager and, through the City Manager, any department of the City
to render such assistance to the Commission as may reasonably be required.
 
   (e)   Duties. The Parks and Recreation Commission shall perform the
following duties:
      (1)   Study and report to Council the problems and needs of the
Municipality regarding parks and recreation facilities, including, but not
limited to, personnel needs, maintenance and operating budgetary needs.
      (2)   Recommend to Council for its approval a master plan for the
development of parks and recreation facilities, including, but not limited to,
capital budgetary needs and recommended priorities, and submit annual or more
frequent, revisions of such master plan thereafter.
      (3)   Advise Council concerning acquisition of property for parks and
recreation purposes, including recommended methods for financing such
acquisition.
      (4)   Advise Council concerning rules, regulations and policies for
operation and use of parks and recreation facilities.
      (5)   Advise Council concerning parks, recreation and cultural programs
for the City.
      (6)   Perform such other duties as shall be directed by Council.
 
   (f)   Meetings, Minutes, Annual Report. The Parks and Recreation Commission
shall meet not less than once each month and all such meetings shall be public.
Minutes of all meetings shall be kept and forwarded to Council, and an annual
report covering the Commission’s activities shall be prepared by the Commission
and furnished to Council in December of each year. The Commission shall make
its own rules of procedures.
(Ord. 84-74. Passed 9-9-74.)
 
   151.04 FIRE AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES ADVISORY BOARD.
   (a)   Members; Term. There is hereby established a Fire and Emergency
Medical Services Advisory Board to be composed of nine members appointed by
Council for terms of one or two years as Council shall determine and specify at
the time of making such appointments, each term commencing on January 1, 1994.
At least three members shall be appointed by the City upon recommendation of
Sharon Township and at least one member shall be appointed by the City upon
recommendation of the Village of Riverlea. Members shall serve for a full term,
except when appointed to fill a vacancy, in which case such members shall serve
for the unexpired term. All members shall serve without pay.
   The representatives shall not be appointed from specific organizations or
groups; however, Council shall endeavor to appoint persons representative of
all areas of the delivery of quality fire and emergency medical services within
the area that the Division of Fire and Emergency Medical Services will serve
upon its transfer to the City.
 
   (b)   Organization. The Advisory Board shall organize annually in January
and elect a chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary.
 
   (c)   Advisory Capacity Only. The Advisory Board shall act solely in an
advisory capacity to Council and all reports and proposals shall be made to
Council.
 
   (d)   Departmental Assistance. The Advisory Board may call upon the City
Manager and, through the City Manager, any department of the City to render
such assistance to the Advisory Board as may reasonably be required.
 
   (e)   Duties. The Advisory Board shall perform the following duties:
      (1)   Study and report to Council problems and needs regarding fire and
emergency medical services, including but not limited to, personal needs,
maintenance, and operating budgetary needs.
      (2)   Advise Council concerning rules, regulations and policies for the
operation of the Division of Fire and Emergency Medical Services.
      (3)   Perform such other duties as shall be directed by Council.
 
   (f)   Meetings and Minutes. The Advisory Board shall meet not less than
bimonthly and all such meetings shall be public. Minutes of all meetings shall
be kept and forwarded to Council. The Advisory Board shall make its own rules
and procedures.
(Ord. 87-93. Passed 10-12-93.)
 
 
 
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial
         Chap.
161.    Mayor's Court.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 161
Mayor's Court
 
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Mayor has jurisdiction to hear and determine any
prosecution for the violation of a Municipal ordinance, and has jurisdiction in
all criminal causes involving moving traffic violations occurring on State
highways located within the corporate limits, subject to the right of the
defendant to trial by jury and before an impartial magistrate.
   Ohio R.C. 2945.17 provides that an accused has a right to be tried by a jury
at any trial in any court for the violation of any Ohio statute or of any
Municipal ordinance, except in cases in which the penalty involved does not
exceed a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Ohio R.C. 2937.08 and Criminal
Rule 23(A) provide that if the court in which a defendant is charged with an
offense is not a court of record (the Mayor's Court), and the charge is such
that a right to a jury trial exists, such matter shall not be tried before him
and shall be transferred to a court of record in the County if the defendant:
   (a)   Does not waive his right to trial by jury in a serious offense case
for which the penalty established by laws includes confinement for more than
six months, or
   (b)   Demands a jury trial in a petty offense case in which the penalty
prescribed is a fine greater than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and/or
imprisonment for not more than six months. "Such demand must be in writing and
filed with the clerk of court not less than ten days prior to the date set for
trial, or on or before the third day following receipt of notice of the date
set for trial, whichever is later. Failure to demand a jury trial as provided
in this subdivision is a complete waiver of the right thereto."
      In Ward v. Village of Monroeville, Ohio, 93 S. Ct. 80 (1972), the United
States Supreme Court held that where the mayor before whom the defendant was
compelled to stand trial was responsible for municipal finances and the mayor's
court provided a substantial portion of municipal revenues, defendant was
denied a trial before a disinterested and impartial magistrate as guaranteed by
the due process clause of the United States Constitution.
   The Supreme Court of Ohio has adopted the "Ohio Traffic Rules" which
prescribe the procedure to be followed in the Mayor's Court in traffic cases.
Rule 9(A) thereof states the jury demand shall be made pursuant to Criminal
Rule 23 referred to above. Rule 9(B) sets forth the conditions under which the
Mayor may hear a traffic case incorporating therein the holding in Ward v.
Village of Monroeville as further interpreted in State, ex rel. Brockman v.
Procter, 35 Ohio St. 2d 79 (1973): "Where, in a mayor's court, a defendant is
entitled to a jury trial and a jury demand is made pursuant to Criminal Rule
23, the Mayor shall transfer the case pursuant to subdivision (C). If a jury
demand is not made pursuant to Criminal Rule 23, and (or?) the defendant waives
his right to jury trial in writing, a mayor may try the case if (1) his
compensation as a judge is not directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions, or (2) he is not the chief executive and administrative officer of
the municipality and as such responsible for the financial condition of the
municipality. Guilty and no contest pleas may be taken by any mayor including
mayors whose compensation as a judge is directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions and mayors who as chief executive and administrative officer of the
municipality are responsible for the financial condition of the municipality."
   The procedure for transferring a case to a court of record is
set forth in Rule 9(C): "Where a transfer is required, the mayor's court shall
make a written order directing the defendant to appear at the transferee court,
continuing the same bail, if any, and making appearance before the transferee
court a condition of bail, if any. Upon transfer, the mayor's court shall
transmit to the clerk of the transferee court the ticket and all other papers
in the case, and any bail taken in the case. Upon receipt of such papers the
clerk of the transferee court shall set the case for trial and shall notify the
defendant by ordinary mail of his trial date."
   Rule 13 provides that a court shall establish a traffic violation bureau and
specifies certain restrictions as to the designated offenses and schedule of
fines to be accepted as waiver payment in lieu of court appearance.
 
161.01   Retention of overpayments.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Disposition of fines and costs - see Ohio R.C. 733.40
      Mayor's powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 1905.20 et seq.
      Trial - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 2938
      Notification to Director of liquor law convictions - see Ohio R.C.
4301.991
      Record of traffic violations - see Ohio R.C. 4513.37
 
   161.01 RETENTION OF OVERPAYMENTS.
   Any overpayment of fines and costs to the Worthington Mayor’s Court or
Worthington Violations Bureau where such overpayment is five dollars ($5.00) or
less in excess of the obligation due, such overpayment should be retained by
the City and no refund shall be paid.
(Ord. 06-2001. Passed 2-20-01.)
