941.03 et seq.
 
   903.01  OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS OR ALLEYS.
   No person shall place any obstruction on any public street, sidewalk or
alley unless authorized to do so by the Director of Safety or the Director of
Service.
 
   903.02  EXCAVATION PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall dig in or disturb the surface of any public street or alley
without first having secured a permit from the Building Inspector. The
application for such permit shall be approved by the Director of Service. The
fee for such permit shall be five dollars ($5.00) and the permittee shall cause
the excavation to be made at his own expense. No excavation shall be permitted
which will cause a permanent change in the established grade.
 
   903.03 DEPOSIT OR BOND FOR RESTORATION.
   At the time of securing a permit for street excavation, the applicant shall
deposit one hundred dollars ($100.00) or such larger amount as, in the opinion
of the Director of Service, is adequate for the purpose of replacing the
pavement. Contractors and public utilities engaged in an extensive program
requiring considerable excavation may make a single deposit, in an amount fixed
by the Director of Service, to cover their whole program. If the Director of
Service shall determine that the applicant is financially responsible and
competent to replace the pavement, the applicant may file a bond to cover
satisfactory performance and shall be permitted to refill the excavation and
replace the pavement, subject to inspection and approval by the Director of
Service. The bond shall be returned if performance is satisfactory.
 
   903.04  REFILLING AND RESURFACING.
   All refilling of excavations and all resurfacing of openings in the streets
shall be done by the proper officers and employees of the City, except as
provided in Section
903.03, and the cost of such refilling and resurfacing shall be charged to the
holder of the permit under which the openings were made. Such part of such
deposit as may remain after deducting the cost of refilling and resurfacing
shall be returned to the applicant upon the completion of resurfacing. If the
cost of such resurfacing is more than the amount deposited, such excess shall
be collected from the applicant.
 
   903.05 CORRUGATED, SPIKED OR RIBBED METAL WHEELS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall propel or cause to be propelled over any paved street any
vehicle or piece of machinery the wheels or carrying device of which are
corrugated, spiked or ribbed metal, or which present to the street any except a
smooth surface, and of a width commensurate with the weight carried. This
section shall not apply to vehicles with pneumatic tires.
 
   903.06  LITTERING.
   No person shall throw, drop, deposit or leave in or upon any part of any
street, alley, public park or place any waste paper, ashes, bottles, glass,
grass, leaves, rubbish or other refuse matter of any kind or description.
 
   903.07 ADVERTISING ACROSS STREETS.
   No person shall erect or suspend any sign, rope or wire across any street or
alley for advertising purposes.
 
   903.08 DRIVEWAYS; PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE AND DEPOSIT.
   No person shall make or construct any driveway or entrance from any public
street or alley in the City across and over any public right of way, sidewalk
or curb upon any such street or alley, and to any private property bounding or
abutting on any such street or alley, or remove or disturb any part of such
right of way, sidewalk or curb on any such street or alley, for the purpose of
installing a driveway or entrance without first obtaining a permit to do so
from the Director of Service.
   Whenever any construction is to be undertaken on any lot to which access for
materials and equipment can be secured only from an improved street, the owner,
contractor or builder who is undertaking the construction shall, whenever there
is a curb and gutter, apply for a permit to cut such curb. Such application
shall be made to the Division of Building Inspection accompanied by a fee of
five dollars ($5.00) and a deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to
guarantee the satisfactory completion of the work including the replacement of
the curb when such replacement is necessary. If the Director of Service, after
inspection, determines that the work has been properly done and that there has
been no unnecessary damage to the portion of the curb not so cut during the
construction, the deposit shall be returned after the construction project has
been completed.
   All permits herein provided for shall become null and void ninety days from
the date of issuance if not used, and any money paid therefor shall in no case
be refunded unless such unused permit is returned within such ninety days after
the date of issuance. No permit shall be issued except to the owner of the
premises or his authorized agent or contractor. The Director of Service may
refuse any permit in any case when, in the interests of public safety, such
permit ought not be granted. (Ord. 14-67. Passed 2-27-67.)
 
   903.09 DRIVEWAY REQUIRED AT CONSTRUCTION SITES.
   In order to minimize the carrying of mud and other debris onto the streets
and to lessen traffic hazards at construction sites, the contractor or builder,
before proceeding with the construction, enlargement, alteration, repair or
removal of any building or other structure, shall construct a driveway from the
edge of the pavement to the setback building line. Such driveway shall be at
least eight feet in width and shall be constructed with a minimum depth of four
inches of gravel or crushed stone, unless a driveway at least equal in
specifications is already available and in use.
 
   903.10 DRIVEWAY WIDTHS: COMPLIANCE AND EXCEPTIONS.
   No single driveway or entrance shall exceed thirty feet in width at the curb
line in residential districts. Driveways in all other districts may be forty-
five feet in width at the curb line. No more than one driveway or entrance
shall be permitted to any property abutting any street wherein the property has
a frontage of less than 200 feet; however, in hardship cases where the public
interest in involved, Council may, upon proper application and payment of the
required fee by the property owner or his authorized agent, by resolution,
authorize the Director of Service to issue a driveway or entrance permit in
excess of 30 feet for residential or 45 feet in the case of all other uses and
to issue more than one driveway or entrance permit where abutting property has
a frontage of less than 200 feet.
(Ord. 36-95. Passed 6-12-95.)
 
   903.11 PERMIT FOR STREET USE.
      Upon proper application, the Director of Safety, or their designee, may
authorize the use of a public street for the purpose of neighborhood gatherings
provided they are satisfied that the temporary blocking of the street to
vehicular traffic would not be detrimental to the community safety and will not
bring or create a hardship or prevent emergency vehicles from gaining access to
scenes of emergency. The applicant for a use of street permit shall be
responsible for the safekeeping of any equipment provided by the City.
(Ord. 46-2021. Passed 10-4-21.)
 
   903.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of Section
903.01 or
903.06 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
 
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
903.02,
903.07 or
903.08 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
 
   (c)   Whoever fails to comply with the requirements of Section
903.09 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
 
   (d)   Whoever violates Section
903.10 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. Each twenty-four hours
of continued violation shall constitute a separate offense.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 905
Sidewalk Specifications
 
905.01   Types of sidewalks permitted.
905.02   Construction permit required.
905.03   Inspection required.
905.04   Material specifications.
905.05   Construction specifications.
905.06   Maintenance bond.
905.07   Special conditions.
905.08   Petition by property owners.
905.09   City and property owner participation in cost of sidewalk
construction.
905.10   Payment by property owners.
905.11   Payment by property owners for additional costs for the use of
alternative sidewalk materials.
905.12   Other sidewalk installation.
905.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Notice to construct or repair - see Ohio R.C. 729.03 et seq.
      Protection of sidewalks - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
907
      Sidewalk to be constructed in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1103.10
      Driveways and curbs - see P. & Z.
1103.09
 
   905.01  TYPES OF SIDEWALKS PERMITTED.
   All sidewalks hereafter constructed within the public right of way along any
City street or highway shall be constructed according to material and
construction specifications set forth in Sections
905.04 and
905.05.
   Such sidewalks shall be constructed of either:
   (a)   Portland cement concrete;
   (b)   Paving bricks set in a cement mortar setting bed upon a Portland
cement concrete foundation; or
   (c)   Paving bricks set in a sand bed upon a compacted soil base.
      (Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
 
   905.02  CONSTRUCTION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No property owner, agent or contractor shall construct any sidewalk within
the public right of way along any City street or highway without first
obtaining a permit from the Director of Service. There shall be no charge for
such a permit.
(Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
 
   905.03  INSPECTION REQUIRED.
   When a sidewalk construction permit is issued, according to the conditions
set forth in Section
905.04 construction shall take place under the supervision and control of, and
to the satisfaction and approval of the Building Inspector, or authorized
representative.
   (a)   The Department of Engineering shall be notified at least twenty-four
hours in advance of all work, so that inspection may be scheduled.
   (b)   No concrete shall be placed until forms have been inspected and
approved by the Building Inspector, or authorized representative.
      (Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
 
   905.04 MATERIAL SPECIFICATIONS.
   All sidewalks constructed within the public right of way of any City street
or highway shall be constructed with materials that meet the following
specifications.
   (a)   Cement. Cement shall be Portland cement and shall be a brand that is
approved and accredited by the Portland Cement Association.
   (b)   Aggregate. Fine aggregate shall be natural sand. Coarse may be
furnished in a two size mix, No. 4 and No. 6 or a single size, No. 57. All
aggregate shall comply with the requirements of Section 499 of the City of
Columbus Construction and Material Specifications Manual (current edition).
   (c)   Concrete. Concrete mix shall comply with the requirements of Section
499 of the City of Columbus Construction and Material Specifications Manual
(current edition).
   (d)   Mortar. Mortar shall be type M Portland cement-lime mortar.
Proportions by volume shall be one part Portland cement, one fourth part
hydrated lime and three parts natural sand.
   (e)   Paving Bricks. Bricks shall conform to ASTM C-62 Grade SW. Minimum
thickness shall be two inches. Other dimensions, color and shape of the bricks
shall be approved, prior to installation by the Director of Service from
samples.
   (f)   Joint Filler. Expansion joints shall be filled with a premolded
bituminous filler material one-half inch wide by four inches deep, for the full
width of the sidewalk.
      (Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
 
   905.05 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS.
   All sidewalks constructed within the public right of way of any City street
or highway shall be constructed in accordance with the following
specifications.
   (a)   All Sidewalks.
      (1)   Width. All sidewalks shall be a uniform width of four feet.
      (2)   Slope. The ground from the street side edge of the sidewalk to the
curb, shall slope at a rate of five-eighths of an inch per foot, plus a one-
inch raise at the curb. The sidewalk shall slope toward the curb at a rate of
one- quarter inch per foot (plus or minus one-eighth inch per foot).
      (3)   Location. The street side edge of the sidewalk shall be located no
closer than five feet from the back edge of the curb.
      (4)   Line and grade. All sidewalks shall conform to alignment and grade
specifications as shown on the construction plans submitted by the property
owner, agent or contractor, and approved by the Director of Service.
      (5)   Utilities and drainage. Water valve boxes that fall within the
sidewalk shall be protected during construction and shall be set flush with the
finished grade of the sidewalk. Roof drains shall be extended under sidewalks
and through curbs.
   (b)   Concrete Sidewalks.
      (1)   Preparation. Concrete shall be placed on an even and compact
subgrade surface free of soft soil, vegetation or other organic material. The
subgrade shall be kept damp in advance of placing concrete, to prevent loss of
moisture from the concrete.
      (2)   Forms. Forms shall be set true to line and grade, and shall be well
supported so that sagging, shifting, twisting or other deformation of the form
does not occur. Form shall be coated with oil approved by the Building
Inspector, or authorized representative, immediately prior to placing concrete.
      (3)   Compaction. When placed, the concrete shall be compacted or
vibrated, by mechanical methods, so that it is thoroughly worked into all
corners, joints and form surfaces.
      (4)   Thickness. Minimum thickness of concrete shall be four inches,
except at driveway crossing, where the minimum thickness shall be six inches.
No grade depressions shall be allowed at driveway crossings.
      (5)   Expansion joints. An expansion joint, perpendicular to the line of
the sidewalk, shall be installed at all points where concrete touches the curb,
an existing sidewalk or a building foundation, as well as along the new
concrete sidewalk at intervals not to exceed forty feet.
      (6)   Finishing. The surface of the concrete shall be screeded at least
twice to obtain a uniform finish. It shall then be smoothed with a wooden
float, then broomed to produce a nonskid surface. The edges of the concrete
sidewalk shall be rounded to a one-quarter inch radius with an edging tool at
least two inches wide. Transverse joints shall be at intervals of not less than
four nor more than six feet and shall be cut into the surface of the concrete
with a jointing tool at least three inches wide, with a projecting cutting edge
at least one and one-half inches in depth.
      (7)   Curing. After the final finishing and after all free water has
disappeared from the surface of the concrete all exposed surfaces of the
concrete shall be either sprayed with white or colorless concrete during
compound, or covered with wet straw or burlap for seven days. If curing
compound is used, it shall be of a type approved by the Building Inspector, or
authorized representative. If burlap or straw is used, it shall be kept wet for
the seven day period.
      (8)   Temperature limits. No concrete shall be placed without permission
of the Director of Engineering when the temperature, as recorded by the
National Weather Service Columbus Bureau, falls below thirty-two degrees
Fahrenheit.
      (9)   Precast material. Precast concrete slabs, with a minimum size of
four feet by four feet, may be used with approval of the Director of Service,
provided they meet all other requirements and specifications set forth in this
chapter.
   (c)   Brick Sidewalks on Concrete.
      (1)   Preparation. The concrete foundation shall meet all specifications
for concrete sidewalks set forth in subsection (b) hereof, except for
requirements for minimum thickness, which shall be three inches except at
driveway crossings, which shall be six inches.
      (2)   Setting bed. Paving brick shall be placed upon the cured concrete
foundation in a cement mortar setting bed with a minimum thickness of one inch.
      (3)   Joints. Cement mortar shall be placed in all joints between paving
bricks. Joints shall be a minimum width of one-quarter inch and a maximum width
of one-half inch.
      (4)   Curing. Cement mortar shall be allowed to cure for forty-eight
hours before traffic is permitted on the sidewalk.
      (5)   Temperature limits. No mortar shall be placed without permission of
the Director of Engineering when the temperature, as recorded by the National
Weather Service Columbus Bureau, falls below thirty-two degrees Fahrenheit.
      (6)   Used material. Salvaged brick shall not be permitted, except when
such bricks have a demonstrated suitability for paving, such as brick
previously used for street paving.
      (7)   Patterns. Paving brick shall be set according to one of four
patterns; running bond, herringbone, soldier course or basketweave. Such
patterns are represented in City Standard Drawing No. 905A-83. All other
patterns shall be approved only by resolution of Council.
   (d)   Brick Sidewalks on Sand.
      (1)   Preparation. The subgrade surface shall be even and well compacted,
with all soft soil, vegetation and other organic material removed and replaced
with soil approved by the Building Inspector or authorized representative.
Before paving bricks are placed, the subgrade shall be treated with a soil
sterilizer to retard growth of weeds and grass.
      (2)   Sand bed. A two-inch layer of sand shall be placed on the prepared
subgrade and spread uniformly with a screed. The sand shall be wetted, then
compacted by hand or mechanical tamp. Additional screeding shall be done, as
needed, to smooth sand and to bring the surface of the sand to exact grade.
      (3)   Joints. Paving bricks shall be placed tightly together. No joints
or open spaces shall be left between bricks.
      (4)   Driveway base. A concrete base, with a minimum thickness of six
inches and conforming to specifications set forth in subsection (b) hereof,
shall be installed at driveway crossings. Paving brick placed across the
driveway base shall be set in a cement mortar setting bed with a minimum
thickness of one inch. The cement mortar shall be allowed to cure for forty-
eight hours before traffic is permitted on the sidewalk.
      (5)   Edging. Rigid edging shall be accomplished by one of the following
methods:
         A.   A soldier course of paving brick, set in concrete according to
details set forth in City Standard Drawing No. 905B-83, shall be placed along
both the street side and house side edges of the sidewalk, and at each property
line; or
         B.   A staked screed, two inches by four inches or larger, of cedar or
a pressure treated wood, shall be permanently placed on edge along both the
street side and the house side edges of the sidewalk. The top of the screed
shall be no more than one inch below the finish grade of the sidewalk.
      (6)   Used material. Salvaged brick shall not be permitted, except when
such bricks have a demonstrated suitability for paving, such as brick
previously used for street paving.
      (7)   Patterns. Paving bricks shall be set according to one of four
patterns; running bond, herringbone, soldier course or basketweave. Such
patterns are represented in City Standard Drawing No. 905A-83. All other
patterns shall be approved only by resolution of Council.
         (Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
   (e)   Brick Sidewalks on Concrete Base With Bituminous Setting Bed.
      (1)   Preparation. The concrete foundation shall have a minimum depth of
four inches, except at driveway crossings, which shall be six inches set on a
compacted subgrade.
      (2)   Setting bed. Paving brick shall be placed upon the cured concrete
foundation in a bituminous setting bed comprised of asphalt cement with a
neoprene tack coat. Such setting bed shall have a minimum depth of three-
quarters of an inch.
      (3)   Joints. Paving bricks shall be placed tightly together with mason's
sand or a mixture of sand and cement placed between bricks. Expansion joints
perpendicular to the line of the sidewalk shall be placed at intervals not to
exceed forty feet.
      (4)   Edging. Rigid edging shall be provided by the placement of a
soldier course or rowlock of paving brick set in concrete or in mortar.
      (5)   Used material. Salvaged brick shall not be permitted, except when
such bricks have a demonstrated suitability for paving, such as brick
previously used for street paving.
      (6)   Patterns. Paving bricks shall be set according to one of four
patterns; running bond, herringbone, soldier course or basketweave. Such
patterns are represented in City Standard Drawing No. 905A-83. All other
patterns shall be approved only by resolution of Council.
         (Ord. 79-89. Passed 9-11-89.)
 
   905.06  MAINTENANCE BOND.
   All sidewalks constructed within the public right of way of any City street
or highway by a person other than the property owner shall be guaranteed for a
period of one year against cracking, settling, disintegrating or any other
structural defect resulting from improper workmanship or material failure.
   Such guarantee shall be in the form of a surety bond, for the full amount of
the work posted within the Director of Service and held by the City.
(Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
 
   905.07  SPECIAL CONDITIONS.
   Council may direct, by ordinance, that a sidewalk within the public right of
way along any City street or highway be placed in a different location (within
reference to grade and alignment), if such a move is needed to conform to an
existing sidewalk or to meet special conditions, If a sidewalk is installed at
the direction of Council, the ordinance shall specify the sidewalk’s line and
grade. (Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
 
   905.08  PETITION BY PROPERTY OWNERS.
   (a)   The Director of Service shall cause sidewalks to be installed within
the public right of way of any block, upon receipt of a written petition signed
by the owners of not less than fifty- one percent (51%) of the platted lots on
said block, if:
      (1)   Their lots do not have a sidewalk in the public right of way for
which the petition is submitted; or
      (2)   Their lots do not have a sidewalk that has been constructed in
accordance with Section
1103.10.
   A corner lot shall be counted in determining compliance with the fifty-one
percent (51%) requirement set forth above, irrespective of whether the
structure, if any, located on said corner lot fronts on the public right of way
for which the petition is submitted or on the intersecting public right of way.
(Ord. 01-2002. Passed 1-22-02.)
 
   (b)   For purposes of this section,
      (1)   A “block” means one side of a public street right of way between
two intersecting public street rights of way.
      (2)   An “owner” means all of the owners of a lot as recorded in the
official records of the office of the Franklin County Recorder.
         (Ord. 46-95. Passed 7-24-95.)
 
   905.09 CITY AND PROPERTY OWNER PARTICIPATION IN COST OF SIDEWALK
CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   In connection with the construction of sidewalks pursuant to Section
 905.08, the City shall, subject to the provisions of Section
905.11 pay for:
      (1)   The preparation of plans and specifications;
      (2)   The costs associated with advertising for bids and awarding a
contract and for construction inspection;
      (3)   The costs associated with an Assessment Equalization Board; and
      (4)   Fifty percent (50%) of the cost of sidewalk construction.
   In connection with the construction of sidewalks pursuant to Section
905.08, the property owners shall, subject to the provisions of Section
905.11, collectively pay fifty percent (50%) of the cost of construction and
shall individually pay an amount for each of their respective lots, determined
as set forth below.
(Ord. 46-95. Passed 7-24-95.)
 
   (b)   Upon completion of the sidewalk construction, the Director of Public
Service shall determine:
      (1)   The total cost of construction (exclusive of those costs set forth
in subsections (a)(1), (2) and (3) hereof) of the sidewalks installed in the
blocks;
      (2)   The total number of lineal feet of sidewalks installed, and
      (3)   The cost per lineal foot by dividing subsection (b)(1) by (b)(2).
The owners of lots shall pay an amount equal to the cost per lineal feet of
sidewalk constructed on their lots. (Ord. 57-95. Passed 9-25-95.)
 
   905.10  PAYMENT BY PROPERTY OWNERS.
   Property owners may pay their individual portion of the cost of the sidewalk
construction either:
   (a)   In cash within sixty days after notification from the City of the
amount due for said construction; or
   (b)   By way of special assessment in accordance with Chapter 727 of the
Ohio Revised Code, levied against the benefited property, payable in not more
than five annual installments, with interest at such rate as shall be
determined by City Council.
      (Ord. 46-95. Passed 7-24-95.)
 
   905.11 PAYMENT BY PROPERTY OWNERS FOR ADDITIONAL COSTS FOR THE USE OF
ALTERNATIVE SIDEWALK MATERIALS.
   Whenever a petition of property owners, as required by Section
905.08, specifies sidewalk construction materials other than concrete, the City
share of the cost of said construction shall be limited to an amount equal to
fifty percent (50%) of the cost of construction had concrete been used instead
of the alternative material. Property owners shall pay the balance of the cost
of construction determined pursuant to Section
905.09 and in one of the methods set forth in Section
905.10. (Ord. 46-95. Passed 7-24-95.)
 
   905.12 OTHER SIDEWALK INSTALLATION.
   Nothing contained in this chapter shall prevent the City from proceeding
with the installation of sidewalks pursuant to Chapter 729 of the Ohio Revised
Code.
(Ord. 46-95. Passed 7-24-95.)
 
   905.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for each offense. Each twenty-four hours of continued violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 61-83. Passed 8-8-83.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 907
Protection of Sidewalks and Curb Ramps
 
907.01   Definitions.
907.02   Storage or display on sidewalks and curb ramps prohibited.
907.03   Sidewalk and ramp cleaning.
907.04   Sidewalk and ramp repair.
907.05   Temporary pathway.
907.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Sidewalk notice to repair - see Ohio R.C. 729.03 et seq.
      Riding, parking on sidewalks - see TRAF.
331.37 ,
351.03
      Malicious destruction of property - see GEN. OFF.
541.04
      Sidewalk construction permit - see S.U. & P.S.
 905.02
      Park strip (tree lawn) - see S.U. & P.S.
941.03  et seq.
   907.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this Chapter:
   (a)   “Curb ramp” means a sloping surface constructed by the City of
Worthington to assist persons at intersections where walkways cross a curb.
   (b)   “Curb ramp structure” means any of the following complex curb ramps
built throughout the City of Worthington:
      (1)   NE corner of Oxford Street and Short Street.
      (2)   NE corner of Oxford Street and New England Avenue.
      (3)   SE corner of Oxford Street and New England Avenue.
      (4)   NE corner of Oxford Street and West Dublin-Granville Road.
      (5)   NW corner of Oxford Street and West Dublin-Granville Road.
      (6)   SE corner of Oxford Street and West Dublin-Granville Road.
      (7)   SW corner of Oxford Street and West Dublin-Granville Road.
      (8)   NE corner of High Street and North Village Green Drive.
      (9)   East side of High Street at Short Street.
         (Ord. 15-2005. Passed 5-2-05.)
   907.02 STORAGE OR DISPLAY ON SIDEWALKS AND CURB RAMPS PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No person shall store or display or cause to be stored or displayed
upon any sidewalk any goods, wares or merchandise or cause or permit any goods,
wares or merchandise to be deposited upon any sidewalks or other public
property, except for such time as may be necessary for loading or unloading the
same or where permit has been issued pursuant to Section
903.01.
   (b)   No person shall store or display or cause to be stored or displayed
upon any curb ramp or curb ramp structure, any goods, wares or merchandise or
cause or permit any goods, wares or merchandise to be deposited upon any curb
ramp or curb ramp structure.
(Ord. 15-2005. Passed 5-2-05.)
   907.03  SIDEWALK AND RAMP CLEANING.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any parcel of land in
the City abutting on a public street where a sidewalk has been constructed to
keep such sidewalk, including curb ramps free of accumulations of rubbish, mud,
ice or snow. The owner or occupant shall remove snow and ice from sidewalks and
curb ramps abutting their respective premises within twelve (12) hours of
daylight after any snowfall or accumulation of ice occurs in order to give safe
passage to all persons.
   (b)   The Director of Service shall issue snow and ice removal notices to
owners or occupants of real estate whose sidewalks are in violation of the
provisions of this section. Such notice to clean sidewalks and curb ramps shall
require such work to be accomplished within twenty-four (24) hours from the
date of such notice.
   (c)   In the event an owner or occupant fails to properly remove ice and
snow from the sidewalks and curb ramps abutting his property after receiving a
subsection (b) notice from the Director of Service, the City may undertake the
removal of the snow and ice. In such event, the cost to the City of such
removal shall be billed to the owner of the premises. Unless paid within thirty
(30) days of receipt, such cost shall be charged against the real estate upon
which the sidewalk is located and shall be a lien upon such real estate.
   (d)   It shall be the duty of the City of Worthington to keep curb ramp
structures free of accumulations of rubbish, mud, ice or snow.
(Ord. 15-2005. Passed 5-2-05.)
   907.04  SIDEWALK AND RAMP REPAIR.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any parcel of land in
the City abutting on a public street where a sidewalk has been constructed to
keep such sidewalk in good repair.
   (b)   The owner or occupant shall also cause such sidewalk to be kept level
and safe for all persons using it. Trees, bushes and hedges located on private
property shall be kept trimmed by the property owner or occupant so that they
do not interfere with the use of the sidewalks. Retaining walls, ditches, and
fences shall be kept in repair and adequately safeguarded to prevent injury to
users of the sidewalk.
   (c)   Any owner, occupant or other person who shall take up, or cause to be
taken up, the whole or part of any paved sidewalk, curb or gutter for the
purpose of improvement or otherwise shall cause such sidewalk, curb or gutter
to be repaired in a proper manner (see Chapter
905) within fourteen (14) days after taking such sidewalk, curb or gutter up,
except that the Director of Service may, upon request, by written permit,
extend the time for such repairing for any period up to but not exceeding
twenty-eight (28) days.
   (d)   In furtherance of the obligation of the owner or occupant of land
within the City to repair, pave or repave sidewalks, curbs, or gutters, as
stated in subsection (c) hereof, such owner or occupant shall cause such
sidewalks, curbs, or gutters to be placed in good and safe condition through
repairing, paving or repaving within twenty-one (21) days after the Director of
Service has directed the same to be done.
   (e)   The Director of Service shall issue repair notices to owners or
occupants of real estate whose sidewalks are in violation of the provisions of
this section. Such notice to repair, pave or repave sidewalks shall require
such work to be accomplished within thirty (30) days from the date of such
notice.
   (f)   The Director of Service shall cause the repair, paving or repaving of
all sidewalks of those properties found to be in violation of the provisions of
subsection (e) hereof and shall present to the owners of such properties for
payment such administrative, construction and other charges as may be incurred
in making such repairs, paving or repaving.
   (g)   If any such invoice delivered to the owners of such properties as set
forth in subsection (f) hereof is not paid within thirty (30) days of receipt,
and if such owner has not contacted the Director of Service to discuss and
decide upon optional methods of payment within such thirty-day period, then the
cost of such repair, paving or repaving shall be charged against the real
estate upon which the sidewalk is located and shall be a lien upon such real
estate.
   (h)   It shall be the duty of the City of Worthington to keep all curb
ramps, curb ramp structures and associated retaining walls in good repair.
(Ord. 15-2005. Passed 5-2-05.)
   907.05 TEMPORARY PATHWAY.
   (a)   No person shall cause any portion of a sidewalk to be blocked or
removed for any purpose without providing a safe and adequate temporary pathway
for pedestrian traffic. Such temporary pathway shall be kept free of debris,
mud, ice or snow. Should pedestrian traffic be routed into streets or alleys,
such temporary pathway shall be protected by the construction of such
barricades, railings, warning lights or other safety devices as may be
specified by the Director of Service.
   (b)   No person shall cause any portion of a curb ramp, or curb ramp
structure to be blocked or removed for any purpose.
(Ord. 15-2005. Passed 5-2-05.)
   907.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of Section
907.02 or 907.05 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (b)   Whoever neglects or refuses to fulfill the obligations imposed by
Section
907.03 or
907.04 within the time prescribed is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for each
offense. For Section
907.03, a separate offense shall be construed to mean every two-day period such
violation continues after the initial offense. For Section
907.04, a separate offense shall be construed to mean every seven-day period
such violation continues after the initial offense.
   (c)   Whoever fails or refuses to pay the charges incurred under Section
 907.03 or
907.04 upon presentation of the same by the Director of Service is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree. (Ord. 15-2005. Passed 5-2-05.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 909
Street Lighting Specifications
 
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Ordinance 49-69, passed December 8, 1969, grants an electric
franchise to the Columbus Southern Power Company through December 31, 1994.
Rate ordinances are adopted periodically.
 
909.01   Residential street lighting; specifications.
909.02   Petition by property owners.
909.03   Special lights; additional costs.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      City consent for electrical fixtures and lines - see Ohio R.C. 715.27,
4933.03, 4933.13, 4933.16
      Protection of street lights - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
911
      Utilities within street right of way - see P. & Z.
1103.14
 
   909.01 RESIDENTIAL STREET LIGHTING; SPECIFICATIONS.
   The City will, in accordance with the provisions of Section
909.02, furnish street lights in residential areas. Such street lights shall be
furnished electricity with overhead distribution facilities and have all
fixtures mounted on wood poles, and shall be of 2,500 light lumens per light.
Such lights and poles are to be spaced approximately 250 feet apart and the
cost of electricity for such lights is to be paid for from general funds of the
City, provided that such lights, overhead distribution facilities, fixtures and
poles are available to the City under the contract between the City and the
Columbus Southern Power Company.
 
   909.02 PETITION BY PROPERTY OWNERS.
   The Director of Service is authorized to furnish such street lights,
provided the same are available under the provisions of the contract referred
to hereinabove, when requested in writing by the owners of sixty percent of the
front footage of the abutting properties, or whenever, in the opinion of the
Director, the furnishing of such street lights is necessary, desirable or is
required for the health, welfare, safety and morals of the areas concerned or
of the City.
 
   909.03 SPECIAL LIGHTS; ADDITIONAL COSTS.
   In the event residents of any residential area within the City may now, or
from time to time in the future, desire street lights of different design,
different intervals and/or of additional light lumens per light than provided
in Section
909.01, the City shall pay from its general funds the cost of 2,500 light
lumens per light, at intervals of approximately 250 feet. However, any
additional cost of installation, cost of equipment and/or additional cost of
electricity consumed shall be paid for by the residents of such area by special
assessments as provided for under the statutes of the State, or by contract
between the residents of such area and the Columbus Southern Power Company.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 911

911.99   Penalty.

   911.01 PROHIBITIONS.
   No person shall interfere in any way with the efficient operation of the
street lighting system of the City or any unit thereof, whether by cutting
wires, damaging light bulbs, reflectors, insulators, transformers, poles or
other structures, or by any other method.
 
   911.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
911.01 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be required to
pay the cost of restoring the service interrupted by his unlawful act.

CHAPTER 914
Newspaper Dispenser Regulations
 
914.01   Definitions.
914.02   Newspaper dispenser regulations.
914.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Obstructions in public ways - see TRAF.
311.01
 
   914.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Newspaper dispenser” means any single container, rack, shelf or
device to hold or store publications for distribution including but not limited
to newspapers, catalogs, periodicals or handbills.
   (b)   “Dispensing station” means a group of newspaper dispensers joined
together at a fixed location.
   (c)   “Front, side and rear yards” are as defined in Section
1123.78 of the Planning and Zoning Code.
      (Ord. 31-99. Passed 5-24-99.)
 
   914.02 NEWSPAPER DISPENSER REGULATIONS.
   (a)   No person, company or corporation other than the City shall install
any newspaper dispenser in the street right of way, front, side or rear yards
of any property, or sidewalk area of High Street between South Street and
Village Green Drive North.
   
   (b)   Persons, companies or corporations utilizing City-provided dispensers
shall obtain a permit for such use from the Director of Public Service. The
permit holder shall abide by the rules and regulations set forth in the permit.
 
   (c)   An annual fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) shall be paid to the
City in advance by the permit holder for the use of each individual dispenser.
No more than one permit shall be issued for the same publication at each
dispensing station.
 
   (d)   The Director of Public Service shall have the authority to revoke the
permit for failure by persons, companies or corporations to abide by the rules
and regulations set forth in the permit. (Ord. 31-99. Passed 5-24-99.)
 
   914.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates the provisions of Section
914.02(a) is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each twenty-four hours of continued
violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 31-99. Passed 5-24-99.)

CHAPTER 921
Protection of Sanitary Sewers
 
921.01   Obstructing sewer.   
921.02   Sewer connection required; abandoned privy vaults, etc.
921.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Licensing plumbers - see BLDG. Ch. 1341
      Sewer-water tapping license - see BLDG. Ch. 1345
      Street excavation permit - see S.U. & P.S.
903.02 et seq.
      Water connection permits - see S.U. & P.S.
925.05 et seq.
      Construction in subdivisions required - see P. & Z.
1101.09(b),
1103.14
      Storm waters prohibited in sanitary sewer - see BLDG. 1305.15
 
   921.01  OBSTRUCTING SEWER.
   No person shall place or permit to be placed in any sanitary sewer system
any material or object which shall obstruct the free flow of water and waste
materials therein.
 
   921.02 SEWER CONNECTION REQUIRED; ABANDONED PRIVY VAULTS, ETC.
   No person shall fail, within six months after sewer services shall be made
available to the lot on which his dwelling house or place of business is
located, to connect his sanitary services to such sewer and to discontinue the
use of any septic tank or privy on such premises. Any privy vault, cesspool,
sewage or septic tank or other device for treatment or disposal of sewage shall
be thoroughly cleaned and filled to the ground surface with earth, ashes or
other suitable filling material promptly upon its abandonment.
 
   921.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates Section
921.01 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
 
   (b)   Whoever fails to comply with the provisions of Section
921.02 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day that such failure to comply
continues beyond the end of the six-month period shall constitute a separate
offense.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 922
Residential On-Site Sewage Disposal Facilities
922.01   Operating permit required.
922.02   Issuance of permits.
922.99   Penalty.
   922.01 OPERATING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No property owner shall operate an on-site residential sewage disposal
system without an operating permit issued by the Columbus Board of Health,
acting as the City's designated health services contract provider.
(Ord. 40-2015. Passed 10-19-15.)
   922.02 ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.
   An operating permit shall be issued by the Columbus Board of Health pursuant
to Chapter 225 of the Columbus City Health Code, amended and adopted by the
Columbus Board of Health on December 16, 2014, as the same may be amended,
which Chapter is hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference. Section
225.01 of the Columbus City Health Code approves Chapter 3701-29 of the Ohio
Administrative Code as the minimum compliance standard for enforcement by
Columbus Board of Health.
(Ord. 40-2015. Passed 10-19-15.)
   922.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree. Each consecutive seven days that an unsafe or unlawful
condition is permitted to remain after notice by the Director of Service and
Engineering shall be a separate offense.
(Ord. 09-2013. Passed 4-15-13.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 923
Protection of Storm Sewers
 
923.01   Obstructing drainage ditch prohibited.
923.02   Drainage under driveways; permit and fee.
923.03   Illicit discharge detection and elimination into the storm water sewer
system.
923.04   Waivers.
923.05   Right of entry.
923.06      Storm Water Post Construction Best Management Practices; permit and
fee.
923.07   Inspection of Storm Water Post Construction Best Management Practices.
923.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Malicious property destruction - see GEN. OFF.
 541.04
      Use of sewer surcharge for storm sewers - see S.U. & P.S.
929.03
      Construction in subdivisions required - see P. & Z.
1101.09(e),
1103.07
      Storm water prohibited in sanitary sewers - see BLDG. 1305.15
 
   923.01 OBSTRUCTING DRAINAGE DITCH PROHIBITED.
   No person shall obstruct a drainage ditch, storm sewer or any other storm
drainage device in this City or permit or cause the same to be obstructed in
any manner which will interfere with the free flow of water therein.
(Ord. 50-2005. Passed 11-7-05.)
   923.02 DRAINAGE UNDER DRIVEWAYS; PERMIT AND FEE.
   No person shall construct or install or cause to be constructed or
installed, any driveway or approach to any lot across a drainage ditch, curb or
sidewalk without first obtaining a permit to do so from the Director of
Service. The application for such permit shall show the details of the proposed
construction including the location, size and type of drainage pipe to be used
under such driveway or approach. All driveway drainage pipe shall be installed
and maintained at the expense of the property owner according to specifications
prepared by the Director of Service. The fee for such permit shall be as
specified in Section
903.08.
(Ord. 50-2005. Passed 11-7-05.)
   923.03 ILLICIT DISCHARGE DETECTION AND ELIMINATION INTO THE STORM WATER
SEWER SYSTEM.
   (a)   No person shall introduce or cause to be introduced into a drainage
ditch, storm sewer or any other storm drainage device in this City any
discharge that is not composed entirely of storm water.
   
   (b)   The following discharges are permissible under this section:
      (1)   A discharge authorized by, and in full compliance with, an NPDES
permit;
      (2)   A discharge or flow resulting from fire fighting by the Fire
Department;
      (3)   Agricultural storm water runoff;
      (4)   A discharge or flow from water line flushing or disinfection that
contains no harmful quantity of total residual chlorine or any other chemical
used in line disinfection;
      (5)   A discharge or flow from lawn watering or landscape irrigation;
      (6)   A discharge or flow from a diverted stream flow or natural spring;
      (7)   A discharge or flow from uncontaminated pumped or infiltrated
groundwater or rising groundwater;
      (8)   Uncontaminated discharge or flow from a foundation drain, crawl
space pump, or footing drain;
      (9)   A discharge or flow from a potable water source not containing any
harmful substance or material from the cleaning or draining of a storage tank
or other container;
      (10)   A discharge or flow from air conditioning condensation that is
unmixed with water from a cooling tower, emissions scrubber, emissions filter,
or any other source of pollutant;
      (11)   A discharge or flow from individual car washing;
      (12)   A discharge or flow from a riparian habitat or wetland;
      (13)   A discharge or flow from cold water (or hot water with prior
permission of the Director of Service) used in street washing or cosmetic
cleaning that is not contaminated with any soap, detergent, degreaser, solvent,
emulsifier, dispersant, or any other harmful cleaning substance;
      (14)   Drainage from a private residential swimming pool containing no
harmful quantities of chlorine or other chemicals; drainage from swimming pool
filter backwash is prohibited; or
      (15)   A discharge or flow of uncontaminated storm water pumped from an
excavation.
   (c)   A discharge is prohibited if:
      (1)   The discharge or flow in question has been determined by the
Director of Service to be a source of a pollutant or pollutants to the waters
of the United States or to the drainage ditch, storm water, or other storm
drainage device;
      (2)   Written notice of such determination has been provided to the
discharger; and
      (3)   The discharge has continued after the expiration of the time given
in the notice to cease the discharge.
         (Ord. 50-2005. Passed 11-7-05.)
   923.04 WAIVERS.
   (a)   The Director of Service may exempt a prohibited discharge into a
drainage ditch, storm sewer or any other storm drainage device provided that a
Discharger has demonstrated to the satisfaction of the Director of Service
that:
      (1)   A discharge is deminimus in nature;
      (2)   A discharge will not adversely impact the drainage ditch, storm
water, drainage device or receiving waters; and
      (3)   The discharge is of limited duration.
   (b)   The Director of Service may prescribe the information necessary for a
Discharger to demonstrate entitlement to the waiver in division (a) of this
section.
(Ord. 50-2005. Passed 11-7-05.)
   923.05  RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Director of Service or his representatives may enter upon lands within
the City to inspect or take samples of any discharge into any drainage ditch,
storm sewer or any other storm drainage device. (Ord. 50-2005. Passed 11-7-05.)
   923.06 STORM WATER POST CONSTRUCTION BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES; PERMIT AND
FEE.
   No person shall construct or install or cause to be constructed or
installed, any required Storm Water Post Construction Best Management Practice
or storm water control structure without first obtaining a permit to do so from
the Director of Service and Engineering. The application for such permit shall
show the details of the proposed construction as specified in Section
1103.07 and include a written Operations and Maintenance Agreement to be held
in perpetuity by the property owner. The fee for such permit shall be twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) for each one-fourth acre or portion thereof. (Ord. 09-
2013. Passed 4-15-13.)
 
   923.07 INSPECTION OF STORM WATER POST CONSTRUCTION BEST MANAGEMENT
PRACTICES.
   An inspection shall be conducted annually for compliance with Section
1103.07. A fifty dollar ($50.00) inspection fee shall be paid to the Finance
Director prior to September 30 of each calendar year, and the inspection shall
take place thereafter. A permit shall be issued following satisfactory
inspection and shall be valid from January 1 through December 31 in the next
calendar year or from the date of issuance through December 31 in the same year
for permits issued within the permit period. (Ord. 09-2013. Passed 4-15-13.)
   923.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
923.01,
923.02,
923.03 or
923.05 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day a prohibited discharge occurs
is a separate offense.
(Ord. 50-2005. Passed 11-7-05.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 925
Protection of Water System
 
925.01   Tampering or opening fire hydrants.
925.02   Water conservation emergency; restrictions.
925.03   Water use permit required.
925.04   Damaging water works.
925.05   Water connection permit required.
925.06   Water tap permit fees.
925.07   Permission to open stop cock or turn water on.
925.08   Connections to mains by City employees.
925.09   Tampering with system.
925.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Compulsory water connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06, 743.23
      Tampering; unauthorized connections - see Ohio R.C. 4933.22
      Malicious property destruction - see GEN. OFF.
541.04
      Sewer water tapping license - see BLDG. Ch. 1345
      Sewer connection permits - see S.U. & P.S.
 921.02
      Water contract with Columbus - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
927
      Construction in subdivisions required - see P. & Z.
1101.09(c),
1103.14
 
   925.01  TAMPERING OR OPENING FIRE HYDRANTS.
   No person shall tamper with, open, break off or obstruct access to a fire
hydrant or install any connection to a hydrant without the approval of the
Director of Service.
 
   925.02 WATER CONSERVATION EMERGENCY; RESTRICTIONS.
   Whenever Council shall determine by resolution, on recommendation of the
Director of Service and Engineering, that an emergency exists requiring the
conservation of the water supply of the City, such resolution shall be posted
on the City's website and notice thereof shall be communicated to the general
public by any other media that the Director deems expedient. No person shall
thereafter use water from the public water supply for the washing of vehicles,
sprinkling of lawns or other vegetation or for any purpose other than normal
housekeeping purposes except under such restrictions as may be established in
such resolution.
(Ord. 01-2017. Passed 1-17-17.)
 
   925.03  WATER USE PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall take or in any way use water for private use which is
furnished by the Worthington Water System, unless a permit for such use has
been obtained from the Director of Service.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Applicants for water service in the Worthington area should
keep in mind the fact that the City has a contract for the furnishing of water
by the City of Columbus (See Chapter
927) which requires that permits for water taps be secured from the City of
Worthington before securing a meter from the City of Columbus and making the
connection).
 
   925.04  DAMAGING WATER WORKS.
   No person shall deface, damage, molest or obstruct in any manner any
building, machinery, piping apparatus or other fixtures or appliances of the
water system.
 
   925.05 WATER CONNECTION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No plumber or other person shall make any attachment, addition to or
alteration in any service pipe, cock or any fixture or appliance connected with
the water service, unless he shall first obtain a permit from the Director of
Service for such work. He shall make a written return of the same fully showing
all such connections and extensions together with such other data as may be
required by the rules and regulations of the City.
 
   925.06 WATER TAP PERMIT FEES.
   The water tap permit fees shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for a three-
fourths inch tap and sixty dollars ($60.00) for a one-inch tap.
 
   925.07 PERMISSION TO OPEN STOP COCK OR TURN WATER ON.
   No plumber or other person making any connection with a service pipe or
after making repairs or putting in any new attachment shall leave the stop cock
open or let the water into the premises without first obtaining permission from
the Building Inspector.
 
   925.08 CONNECTIONS TO MAINS BY CITY EMPLOYEES.
   No person other than an authorized employee of the City, acting under the
direction of the Director of Service, shall tap or make any connection with any
main or distributing pipe of the City water system.
 
   925.09  TAMPERING WITH SYSTEM.
   No person, unless authorized by the Director of Service, shall remove the
cover from, turn or otherwise tamper with any valve, stop cock or hydrant
located in any street, alley, or other public place in the City.
 
   925.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 927
Water Contract With Columbus
 
927.01   Water contract with Columbus.
927.02   Water surcharge authorized; billing by Columbus.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Compulsory water connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06, 743.23

      Water connections - see S.U. & P.S.

   927.01 WATER CONTRACT WITH COLUMBUS.
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ordinance 11-2008, passed March 17, 2008, the
City has entered an agreement with the City of Columbus to furnish water to the
City of Worthington. Copies of such agreement are on file with the City Clerk.
 
   927.02  WATER SURCHARGE AUTHORIZED; BILLING BY COLUMBUS.
   (a)   Amount Established. There is hereby established a surcharge of
seventy-five cents (75¢) per 1,000 cubic feet of water used by each and every
consumer of water within the City of Worthington.
 
   (b)   Relation to Water Contract. The surcharge established for consumers
within the City shall be in addition to charges established by the contract
existing between the City of Columbus, Ohio, and the City of Worthington, Ohio.
 
   (c)   Manner of Billing by Columbus. The surcharge shall be included as a
separate item on the bills rendered to consumers of water by the City of
Columbus, Ohio, in accordance with the terms of the contract between Columbus
and Worthington, Ohio.
 
   (d)   Notice to City of Columbus. The Clerk of the City is directed to
forward a copy of this section to the Director of Public Service of the City of
Columbus, Ohio, requesting that the surcharge established herein be included as
a separate item on the bills rendered to water consumers within the City.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 929
Sewer Contract With Columbus; Sewage Disposal
 
929.01   Sewer contract with Columbus.
929.02   Sewer surcharge authorized; billing by Columbus.
929.03   Use of surcharge funds for storm sewers.
929.04   Area and other sewer charges a lien; certification to County Auditor.

CROSS REFERENCES
      Compulsory sewer connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06
      Sanitary connections required if available - see S.U. & P.S.
921.02
      Water contract with Columbus - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
927
      Storm waters prohibited in sanitary sewers - see BLDG. 1305.15
 
   929.01  SEWER CONTRACT WITH COLUMBUS.
   (a)   The City of Worthington and the City of Columbus have entered into a
thirty-year sewer services agreement that will expire in 2050. A copy of the
agreement is on file with the City Clerk.
   (b)   The provisions of Columbus City Code Chapters 1145 and 1147, along
with the rules and regulations issued by the City of Columbus, and all
amendments thereto, relating to the regulation of sewage use are hereby adopted
by reference and made applicable to the City of Worthington.
   (c)   The City of Columbus may administer and enforce the provisions of
Columbus City Code Chapters 1145 and 1147, along with the rules and regulations
issued by the City of Columbus, and all amendments thereto, relating to the
regulation of sewage use within the City of Worthington. City of Columbus
representatives may enter industrial establishments, perform inspections, and
sample waste streams for the purpose of enforcing such provisions.
   (d)   All fees for administering and enforcing Columbus City Code Chapter
1145 shall be collected in accordance with Columbus City Code Chapter 1147.
(Ord. 31-2020. Passed 7-20-20.)
 
   929.02 SEWER SURCHARGE AUTHORIZED; BILLING BY COLUMBUS.
   (a)   Amount Established. There is hereby established a sewage surcharge of
seventy-five cents ($.75) per 1,000 cubic feet of water used by each and every
consumer of water within the City whose residence or establishment is connected
to the sanitary sewerage system of the City.
 
   (b)   Relation to Sewer Contract. The surcharge shall be in addition to
charges established for premises within the City connected to the sanitary
sewerage system of the City, by the contract existing between the City of
Columbus, Ohio, and the City of Worthington.
 
   (c)   Manner of Billing by Columbus. The surcharge shall be included as a
separate item on the bills rendered to consumers of water by the City of
Columbus, Ohio, in accordance with the terms of the aforementioned contract.
 
   (d)   Notice to City of Columbus. The Clerk of the City is directed to
forward a copy of this section to the Director of Public Service of the City of
Columbus, Ohio, requesting that the surcharge established herein be included as
a separate item on the bills rendered to water consumers within the City of
Worthington, Ohio, whose premises are connected to the sanitary sewerage system
of the City of Worthington, Ohio.
 
   929.03 USE OF SURCHARGE FUNDS FOR STORM SEWERS.
   In addition to the purposes for which sewerage surcharge funds may be used
as set forth in this chapter, such funds may also be used for the additional
purpose of the construction and reconstruction of main and interceptor storm
sewers.
(Ord. 72-64. Passed 7-27-64.)
 
   929.04  AREA AND OTHER SEWER CHARGES A LIEN; CERTIFICATION TO COUNTY
AUDITOR.
   The sanitary sewer system capacity charge together with all other sewer
charges provided by the contract between the cities of Worthington and Columbus
are hereby made a lien upon the corresponding lot, parcel of land, building or
premises served by a connection or connections to the sanitary sewage system of
Worthington, such sanitary sewage system being tributary, either directly or
indirectly, to the sanitary sewerage system of the City of Columbus. If the
same is not paid within ninety days after it shall be due and payable, it shall
be certified by the City Clerk to the Auditor of Franklin County, Ohio, who
shall place the same on the County tax duplicate with the interest and
penalties allowed by law, and be collected as other taxes are collected.
(Ord. 8-76. Passed 3-8-76.)
 
   929.05 COLLECTION OF A SEWERAGE CAPACITY CHARGE.
   (a)   For all property and premises connected into the sanitary sewer system
after the effective date of this section, a sewer capacity charge based on the
size of the water tap to said property or premises shall be levied based on the
following schedule:
 
Water Tap Size (inches) System Capacity Fee
3/4                     $1,250.00
1                       2,600.00
1 1/2                   6,850.00
2                       11,750.00
3                       24,450.00
4                       38,250.00
6                       86,250.00
8                       153,050.00
10                      237,800.00
12                      343,750.00
16                      381,450.00
 
   Credit for any existing structure which has a use charge or for an existing
structure enlarged or removed may be applied against the system capacity charge
herein imposed in the amount of the original structure charge up to but not
more than the current charge.
   A deduction may be made from the system capacity herein imposed, whenever,
and to the extent that the owner of the property concerned can show that a
special assessment or charge for trunk storm and sanitary sewer benefit has
been paid, provided that such deduction shall be limited to the amount of such
original payment up to but not more than the amount of current charge.
 
   (b)   For a six-inch house sewer connection there shall be a sewer tap fee
of fifty dollars ($50.00).
 
   (c)   For the removal of any sewer, or any excavation therefor, there shall
be charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. 1-97. Passed 1-13-97.)

CHAPTER 941
Public Parks and Playgrounds
 
941.01   Park supervision by Director of Parks and Recreation.

CROSS REFERENCES

151.03

   941.01  PARK SUPERVISION BY DIRECTOR OR PARKS AND RECREATION.
   All existing public parks and playgrounds in the City, as well as all future
parks and playgrounds which are the property of the City by dedication,
purchase, bequest or otherwise, whether owned by the City alone or jointly with
the board of Education, shall be under the charge and supervision of the
Director of Parks and Recreation so far as the City's participation is
concerned.
(Ord. 81-74. Passed 7-22-74.)
 
   941.02 RULES FOR USE; PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE AND WAIVER.
   The Director of Parks and Recreation shall have authority to make and
enforce reasonable rules for the use by individuals and by groups of the public
parks and playgrounds owned entirely by the City. No person shall assert any
special right to the use of any park, playground or portion thereof except in
compliance with such rules. Groups shall apply for a permit for such special
right, to be issued by the City Clerk in accordance with such rules, with the
approval of the Director of Parks and Recreation. The fee for such permit shall
be three dollars ($3.00), but the payment of such fee may be waived by the
Director in the case of charitable or nonprofit organizations.
 
   941.03 PARK STRIP DEFINED; CARE, PLANTING AND OBSTRUCTIONS.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 941.03 was repealed by Ordinance 61-98,
passed December 14, 1998.)
 
   941.04  CONTROL OF TREES IN PARK STRIP; TRIMMING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 941.04 was repealed by Ordinance 61-98,
passed December 14, 1998.)
 
   941.05 ADVICE FOR PLANTINGS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 941.05 was repealed by Ordinance 61-98,
passed December 14, 1998.)
 
   941.06 TYPES OF TREES PROHIBITED.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 941.06 was repealed by Ordinance 61-98,
passed December 14, 1998.)
 
   941.07 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The following rules and regulations are adopted by Council to be
enforced by the Director of Parks and Recreation for use by individuals and by
groups of the parks owned entirely by the City.
      (1)   No person shall cut, injure, deface, remove or disturb any tree,
shrub, building, fence, bench or other structure, apparatus or property; or
pick, cut or remove any shrub, bush or flower; or mark or write upon any
building, fence, bench or other structure.
      (2)   No person in a park shall start or maintain a fire except in a
place or at a site designated for this purpose or with the approval in the form
of a special permit.
      (3)   No abusive, profane or indecent language, or any conduct that may
threaten others or unduly disturb the peace shall be allowed.
      (4)   No person shall discharge any firearms, fireworks, air rifles,
sling shots, archery or other explosive devices. Nor shall any person throw
stones or other missiles within park areas.
      (5)   Except by special permit, no person shall remain, stay or loiter in
a park after dark unless otherwise posted. Such permit may allow authorized
people to use the facilities in accordance with the specifications of the
permit issued.
      (6)   No person shall sell, offer or solicit for sale any goods,
merchandise, or services without first obtaining a special permit.
      (7)   No person shall use, consume, carry or bring any alcoholic beverage
in or upon any park.
      (8)   No person in a park shall operate or play a radio, television,
musical instrument, amplifying of sound equipment, mobile device, or operate a
radio-controlled device so as to disturb the peace in a park.
      (9)   No person without first obtaining written authorization shall post,
paste or affix any placard, notice or sign within any park.
      (10)   No commercial services, entertainment or exhibition shall be
offered or given in any park unless a special permit is first obtained.
      (11)   No person in a park shall engage in, promote, solicit, or procure
participants for any game which is played for money or other thing of value, or
engage in any form of gambling.
      (12)    No motorized vehicles of any kind (including minibikes and go-
carts), other than City vehicles and except a person acting in compliance with
the Americans with Disabilities Act, shall be allowed to operate in any City
park other than in areas designated for parking.
      (13)    Multi-purpose fields may be reserved for use by obtaining a
permit from the Parks and Recreation Department. Proof of reservation may be
required at the site at any time during the reserved time.
      (14)    No person shall act in such a manner so as to create a
substantial risk of physical harm to any person or property.
         The following rules and regulations are those pertaining specifically
to shelter house areas:
      (15)   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former subsection (15) was repealed by Ordinance
42-2003, passed July 21, 2003.)
      (16)    Key deposit will be forfeited if the shelter house or grounds are
not properly cleared after use or doors/windows are left unlocked.
Organizations with more than two key deposit forfeitures will be refused
further permits for the use of the facilities during any calendar year.
      (17)    Trash must be deposited in containers and left outside of the
building, lights turned off, windows closed and locked, water turned off, fires
extinguished and all exterior doors and other means of entry locked before
leaving the building. The person or persons responsible for any group using
park areas or shelter houses will be held responsible for the removal of all
debris left on the site and may be issued a court citation for littering if the
area is not cleaned after being used.
      (18)   The permit holder shall be held responsible for damage to
facilities due to negligence and/or poor supervision.
      (19)    Fireplace wood or charcoal will be furnished by the permit
holder.
      (20)    An adult supervisor (18 years of age or older) must be present
during the hours covered by the permit.
      (21)    Permits will not be issued for use of:
         A.    Commercial merchandising parties; or
         B.    Commercial meetings of any kind.
      (22)    Application for a use permit must be made with the Department ten
days prior to the date requested for the permit to ensure time for processing.
      (23)    The City of Worthington and the Colonial Hills Civic Association,
in the case of Selby Park Shelter House, assume no responsibility for lost or
stolen articles.
      (24)    Permit date conflicts created by concurrent applications will be
resolved on the following priority basis:
         A.    Official City of Worthington functions;
         B.    Colonial Hills Civic Association functions (for Selby Park);
         C.    Other established civic associations;
         D.    Worthington residency; and
         E.    All other requests in order of date of application.
 
   (b)    Any individual or group found to be in violation of these rules and
regulations shall be subject to the penalty specified by Section
941.99 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Worthington.
 
   (c)    At the time any individual or group seeks a permit for the use of a
public park owned by the City, such individual or group shall be given a copy
of these rules and regulations, and made aware of the penalties associated with
violation of the rules and regulations.
(Ord. 17-2014. Passed 5-19-14.)
 
   941.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 943
Cemeteries
 
943.01   Union cemeteries with Sharon Township.
943.02   Designation of cemeteries.
943.03   Interments at public expense.
943.04   Board of Cemetery Trustees; appointment of Superintendent.
943.05   Clerk-Treasurer; duties.
943.06   Bonds required for Superintendent and Clerk-Treasurer.
943.07   Permanent endowment fund; purpose.
943.08   Size and price of lots; deeds.
943.09   Interment in Worthington Cemetery prohibited.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Burials may be prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 759.05
      Union cemeteries - see Ohio R.C. 759.27 et seq.
      Burial permits - see Ohio R.C. 3705.24 et seq.
      Burial of indigents - see Ohio R.C. 5113.15
 
   943.01 UNION CEMETERIES WITH SHARON TOWNSHIP.
   (a)   Since the City and Sharon Township have jointly acquired title to land
for cemetery purpose under the provisions of Ohio R.C. 759.27, 759.28, 759.29
and their antecedent sections, such land is held in trust for the use of the
inhabitants of the City and the Township in common.
(Ord. 15-69. Passed 5-26-69.)
 
   (b)   The City hereby unites with Sharon Township in the establishment and
management of the Flint Cemetery as a union cemetery under the provisions of
Ohio R.C. 759.27 et seq.
(Ord. 26-2017. Passed 7-17-17.)
 
   943.02  DESIGNATION OF CEMETERIES.
   The union cemetery shall be known as Walnut Grove Cemetery and Flint
Cemetery.
(Ord. 26-2017. Passed 7-17-17.)
 
   943.03  INTERMENTS AT PUBLIC EXPENSE.
   All interments made at public expense shall be in the Walnut Grove Cemetery
or the Flint Cemetery. (Ord. 26-2017. Passed 7-17-17.)
 
   943.04 BOARD OF CEMETERY TRUSTEES; APPOINTMENT OF SUPERINTENDENT.
   The control and management of the union cemeteries shall be vested in a
joint Board of Cemetery Trustees chosen by the City Council and Township
Trustees in joint meeting as provided in Ohio R.C. 759.36. Taxes for cemetery
purposes shall be levied at a joint meeting of the Township Trustees and City
Council. The Board of Cemetery Trustees shall make rules and regulations for
the management of the cemeteries and may delegate the administration of such
rules and regulations to a Cemetery Superintendent, appointed by a majority
vote of the members at such salary as the Board may establish.
(Ord. 16-69. Passed 5-26-69.)
 
   943.05 CLERK-TREASURER; DUTIES.
   One member of the Board of Cemetery Trustees, or a person selected by them,
shall be designated as Clerk-Treasurer, at such salary as the Board may
establish. Such Clerk-Treasurer shall keep the records, receive the moneys due
from taxes and from sale of lots and other cemetery services, keep the same
safely and pay them out upon proper vouchers signed by the Cemetery
Superintendent.
 
   943.06  BONDS REQUIRED FOR SUPERINTENDENT AND CLERK-TREASURER.
   Both the Cemetery Superintendent and the Clerk-Treasurer shall give bond in
such an amount as may be fixed by the Board, issued by a surety company
authorized to do business in this State, the premium of which shall be paid
from cemetery funds. Such bonds shall be approved by the Board of Cemetery
Trustees.
 
   943.07 PERMANENT ENDOWMENT FUND; PURPOSE.
   The Board of Cemetery Trustees may establish a permanent endowment fund for
the express purpose of keeping such cemeteries clean and in good order. For
this purpose it may add to the price regularly charged for lots therein a sum
for such purpose, or receive gifts for such purpose or enter into separate
agreements with the purchasers of lots by which an agreed portion of the
purchase price shall constitute a permanent fund; or receive individual gifts
for such fund, the income thereof to be used for the upkeep and care of such
lots. When any such funds are received or created, they shall be a permanent
fund for such use and the income therefrom shall be used only for such purpose
and the principal sum shall be kept invested under the rules and standards
established by law for investments by fiduciaries.
(Ord. 16-69. Passed 5-26-69.)
 
   943.08 SIZE AND PRICE OF LOTS; DEEDS.
   The Board of Cemetery Trustees shall determine the size and price of
cemetery lots and the terms of payment therefor and the Clerk-Treasurer shall
issue a deed for the lots so sold. No more shall be charged for lots than is
necessary to reimburse the outlay for the purchase of lands and to keep in
order and embellish the grounds, including the salaries paid to the Cemetery
Superintendent and the Clerk-Treasurer for their services in connection with
cemetery administration.
 
   943.09  INTERMENT IN WORTHINGTON CEMETERY PROHIBITED.
   (a)   From and after June 1, 1983, it shall be unlawful for any body to be
interred in the Worthington Cemetery owned by the Worthington United Methodist
Church.
 
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of wrongful interment, a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 45-83. Passed 6-13-83.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 945
Garbage and Refuse Collection
 
945.01   Definitions.
945.02   Residential collection authorized.
945.03   Commercial or industrial refuse collection; hours of operation.
945.04   Accumulations; nuisance declared.
945.05   Weekly residential collection; rules and regulations.
945.06   Service discontinuance; notice.
945.07   Duty to provide containers.
945.08   Container requirements.
945.09   Container location and pickup.
945.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Collection and disposal - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
      Employment of scavengers - see Ohio R.C. 3707.39
      Disposal and transportation on public ways - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20 et
seq.
      Dumping; unlawful accumulations - see GEN. OFF.
 521.08
      Littering - see TRAF.
331.42; GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Loads to be covered - see TRAF.
339.08
 
   945.01  DEFINITIONS.
   The following definitions are hereby adopted for the purposes of this
chapter:
   (a)   "Garbage" includes all putrescible wastes, except sewage and body
waste, and includes vegetable and animal offal, but excludes recognizable
industrial by-products.
      (Ord. 52-81. Passed 7-27-81.)
   (b)   "Refuse" or "rubbish" includes nonputrescible, nonliquid wastes such
as ashes, cinders, tin cans, glass, bottles, rags, wastepaper, wood and paper
boxes. Bulk materials, including but not limited to household furniture,
appliances, other large household objects, automobile parts, broken concrete,
bricks, plastic, lumber, stones and dirt are considered to be “refuse” or
“rubbish” of the type to be collected under Section
945.02 only if it is provided for collection in manageable weights not
exceeding fifty pounds and/or five feet in length.
      (Ord. 103-93. Passed 11-15-93.)
   (c)   "Subscriber" means any householder within the City except an owner,
tenant or occupant of a three or more family dwelling but including residential
condominiums.
   (d)   "Householder" means the head of a family or one maintaining his or her
separate living room or quarters in the City, and includes owners, tenants and
occupants of all single-family, two-family and residential condominium premises
from which garbage or refuse, or both are generated.
      (Ord. 52-81. Passed 7-27-81.)
   (e)   “Yard waste” includes grass clippings, leaves, shrub/tree trimmings
and limbs less than six inches in diameter and other organic waste from yards
and gardens.
   (f)   “Recyclable materials” includes newspaper, glass, aluminum/bi-metal
beverage cans, #1, #2 and #3 plastics, tin/steel food cans, corrugated
cardboard or any other commodity agreed upon by the City, and the person, firm
or corporation with whom the City contracts under Section
945.02.
   (g)   “Solid waste” includes garbage, refuse, rubbish, recyclable materials
and yard waste as defined in this section. (Ord. 103-93. Passed 11-15-93.)
 
   945.02 RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION AUTHORIZED.
   No person, firm or corporation other than the Director of Service or his
authorized agent who holds a lawful contract within this City, shall collect,
remove or transport single-family, two-family or residential condominium solid
waste within this City.
(Ord. 103-93. Passed 11-15-93.)
 
   945.03 COMMERCIAL OR INDUSTRIAL REFUSE COLLECTION; HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (a)   All commercial or industrial refuse collection shall be performed in
the City between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 45-2011. Passed 11-21-11.)
 
   945.04  ACCUMULATIONS; NUISANCE DECLARED.
   No owner, tenant or occupant of any dwelling or place of business shall
allow garbage, refuse, rubbish or recyclable materials to accumulate in or on
his premises for a period in excess of seven days. Fermenting, putrefying or
odoriferous solid waste shall be deemed a nuisance and the person responsible
shall be liable to prosecution.
(Ord. 103-93. Passed 11-15-93.)
 
   945.05 WEEKLY RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Service shall provide for the collection of one-family, two-
family and residential condominium solid waste collection at least every week.
He is hereby authorized and directed to make such rules and regulations with
reference to the handling, collection and disposal of solid waste as may be
necessary, proper or convenient to facilitate their collection and disposal.
(Ord. 103-93. Passed 11-15-93.)
 
   945.06  SERVICE DISCONTINUANCE; NOTICE.
   The Director of Service may discontinue service in case of violation of any
provision of this chapter or any lawful rules and regulations enacted by the
Director of Service pursuant hereto provided that notice of such violation is
first given to the subscriber.
(Ord. 52-81. Passed 7-27-81.)
 
   945.07 DUTY TO PROVIDE CONTAINERS.
   It shall be the duty of the owner, tenant, occupant, agent, manager or
person in charge of every dwelling, apartment or place of business which
accumulates or permits the accumulation of garbage, refuse and/or yard waste to
provide or cause to be provided at all times suitable containers as hereinafter
prescribed. No owner, tenant or occupant of any dwelling who is a subscriber to
the solid waste collection services provided for herein shall permit any
nonsubscriber to share or otherwise use the allowance or portion of the
allowance specified under Section
945.08 nor shall any nonsubscriber to such services attempt to place his
containers at the collection point of a subscriber or to place his solid waste
in the containers of a subscriber.
(Ord. 103-93. Passed 11-15-93.)
 
   945.08 CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS.
   The quantity of solid waste shall not be limited; except that containers
shall not exceed thirty-five gallon capacity and except as provided by the
contractual carrier and approved by Council. Yard waste must be separated from
other solid waste and placed in a separate container or paper bag designated
for yard waste collection. Paper bags or plastic bags designed for refuse
collection may be used. Plastic bags of a mil thickness of at least 2.5 and a
maximum capacity of thirty gallons or eleven pounds are acceptable as are paper
bags designed for refuse collection having a thickness of 1.5 mils and a
maximum capacity of thirty gallons or fifteen pounds. Such plastic or paper
